description: This exam has been retired. CompTIA and the Linux Professional Institute (LPI) have worked in conjunction to create the CompTIA Linux+ certification. The certification covers the basic knowledge required of a junior level Linux administrator. Candidates are expected to be able to work competently across a wide array of environments and skill sets. Unlike many certifications, candidates who complete the Linux+ exams (LX0-101 and LX0-102) are awarded with not one, but two certifications: the CompTIA Linux+ certification and the LPI LPIC-1 certification. That makes this an excellent starting point for people interested in working with Linux as you gain essential base knowledge as well as fill out your resume.

WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

00:00:08.950 --> 00:00:13.340

the Linux+ certification from CompTIA.

4
00:00:13.340 --> 00:00:16.110
This is kind of an interesting
certification compared to

5
00:00:16.110 --> 00:00:17.940
a lot of the ones that CompTIA does,

6

they didn't actually develop.

7

And so that makes it interesting,
so we do wanna talk about it.

8
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:29.570
Kinda what it is, what it covers, and
why CompTIA didn't develop this exam.

9
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:31.270
It's all important stuff to know,

10
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:35.170
so let's just start with
the basics with what is Linux+?

11
00:00:35.170 --> 00:00:37.780
It's a certification from CompTIA,

12
00:00:37.780 --> 00:00:42.590
the same people that bring you A+,
Net+, Security+, they bring you Linux+.

13
00:00:42.590 --> 00:00:46.770
And it's designed to show that
a network or systems administrator

14
00:00:46.770 --> 00:00:51.760
has a basic level of knowledge in
operating Linux servers and workstations.

15
00:00:51.760 --> 00:00:55.760
It's designed to be vendor neutral so
it's not Red Hat only or

16
00:00:55.760 --> 00:00:57.670
Ubuntu canonical, whatever.

17
00:00:57.670 --> 00:01:00.690
It is design to be vendor neutral but

18
00:01:00.690 --> 00:01:04.660
it does actually focus a little bit on
the Red Hat-based Linux products and

19
00:01:04.660 --> 00:01:08.080
the Debian-based Linux products,
which almost everything is these days.

20
00:01:08.080 --> 00:01:11.635
So it does a great job of straddling
the fence between those and

21
00:01:11.635 --> 00:01:16.025
showing concepts, commands,
administration tools and

22
00:01:16.025 --> 00:01:20.980
techniques that apply to both sets of the
Linux distributions that are out there.

23
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:26.210
So it is a great certification in that it
does show you have that general knowledge.

24
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:27.180
Now, in the beginning,

25
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:32.250
CompTIA actually had their own in-house
developed Linux+ certification.

26
00:01:32.250 --> 00:01:35.000
But over time,
they wanted to make it better and

27
00:01:35.000 --> 00:01:37.270
more generally accepted
amongst the community.

28
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:40.150
So instead of continuing to
write the exam themselves,

29
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:44.810
they partnered with the LPI,
the Linux Professional Institute.

30
00:01:44.810 --> 00:01:49.850
LPI actually had, or has, four levels
of Linux certification available,

31
00:01:49.850 --> 00:01:52.780
from basic all the way up to
super mega expert, right?

32
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:55.511
You have to wear suspenders and
have a beard for that one.

33
00:01:55.511 --> 00:01:57.265
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Even if you're a woman.

34
00:01:57.265 --> 00:02:02.260
[LAUGH] And so you know they've
got some really advanced stuff and

35
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:05.640
CompTIA said well you know,
we really just want the lower end, right?

36
00:02:05.640 --> 00:02:08.025
The introductories,
people have the base knowledge,

37
00:02:08.025 --> 00:02:11.330
it's the equivalent of one year of
field experience working with Linux.

38
00:02:11.330 --> 00:02:15.320
That's what they're shooting for
and the LPI said well great.

39
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:19.910
What you can do is you can use our first
two exams for our certification track and

40
00:02:19.910 --> 00:02:24.460
use that to gauge your Linux+ testers,
right?

41
00:02:24.460 --> 00:02:25.910
And so that's what they did,
they partnered up,

42
00:02:25.910 --> 00:02:28.880
it's been a great partnership
between the two organizations.

43
00:02:28.880 --> 00:02:31.850
And so when you look at the CompTIA
webpages, it'll always say,

44
00:02:31.850 --> 00:02:33.859
well look I've got it
pulled up right here.

45
00:02:33.859 --> 00:02:38.612
CompTIA Linux+ Powered by LPI, and
that lets you know that while it is

46
00:02:38.612 --> 00:02:43.580
a CompTIA certification,
it's actually developed by the LPI.

47
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:44.700
On a neat side,

48
00:02:44.700 --> 00:02:48.730
it means when you pass the exams,
you actually get two certifications.

49
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:53.360
You get the CompTIA Linux+ which
is what most of us are after.

50
00:02:53.360 --> 00:02:58.120
And then on the LPI,
Linux Professional Institute, side,

51
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:02.850
you'll see that you actually end up with
what's called their LPIC-1 certification,

52
00:03:02.850 --> 00:03:05.160
Junior Level Linux certification.

53
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:08.640
And to get that you have to
pass their first two exams

54
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:11.330
which are the same exams you
have to take for Linux+.

55
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:14.200
So you actually end up double
certified which is just kind of neat.

56
00:03:15.360 --> 00:03:19.910
Now, CompTIA does stop there at Linux+,
they don't go beyond that.

57
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:22.670
And so if you want to get
more advanced Linux skills,

58
00:03:22.670 --> 00:03:26.290
well that's where you come over to LPI and
you do LPIC-2, LPIC-3, right?

59
00:03:26.290 --> 00:03:30.150
That's how that partnership works, and how
both companies benefit from it and how you

60
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:35.250
benefit from it too, because I'll tell
you a lot of people have heard of Linux+.

61
00:03:35.250 --> 00:03:40.339
It's a very popular certification, not
as many people have heard of LPIC-2 and

62
00:03:40.339 --> 00:03:41.088
LPIC-3.

63
00:03:41.088 --> 00:03:45.590
They're great certifications, believe me,
but not as many people have heard of them.

64
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:48.430
If you want advanced certifications,
they're the way to go, right?

65
00:03:48.430 --> 00:03:51.080
But if you're just trying to do that
entry-level thing, something that's higher

66
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:54.000
visibility is great,
looks great on the resume, so here you go.

67
00:03:55.410 --> 00:03:59.140
All right, now the Linux+ certification
is actually broken up into two exams.

68
00:03:59.140 --> 00:04:00.058
So, we have.

69
00:04:00.058 --> 00:04:01.797
Actually do they show it on this page?

70
00:04:01.797 --> 00:04:06.525
There it is, the LX0-101 and the LX0-102,

71
00:04:06.525 --> 00:04:10.030
two different certification exams.

72
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:15.195
They are a little bit on the pricey side,
as most CompTIA exams have been lately,

73
00:04:15.195 --> 00:04:18.140
they've kind of raised

00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:21.140
But it's right around
180 dollars per exam.

75
00:04:21.140 --> 00:04:24.095
Obviously, it varies based on your country

76
00:04:24.095 --> 00:04:29.248
So to take both of them you

77
00:04:29.248 --> 00:04:34.180
US dollars, so it can be a little
bit pricey, but it is two exams.

78
00:04:34.180 --> 00:04:38.370
90 minutes each, so they're not incredibly

79
00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:41.190
that means you get about a minute and

00:05:04.260 --> 00:05:10.102

.com and they have testing

00:05:15.170 --> 00:05:20.010

00:05:20.010 --> 00:05:23.365
a test and you'll come in and pick what

91
00:05:23.365 --> 00:05:29.485
So we can go to IT and
find old CompTIA in here, there we go.

00:05:29.485 --> 00:05:31.005

00:05:31.005 --> 00:05:33.432
Nice, thank you for

00:05:36.607 --> 00:05:39.227

00:05:39.227 --> 00:05:43.207

00:05:43.207 --> 00:05:47.097
So maybe you are in Paris, France,

98
00:05:48.957 --> 00:05:55.477
And looks like we got a couple there,

99
00:05:55.477 --> 00:05:57.337
See, I'll show off my
witty Parisian knowledge.

100
00:05:57.337 --> 00:05:58.242
>> That's nice, yes.

101
00:05:58.242 --> 00:06:00.170
So, anyhow you can see some

00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:01.330

00:06:01.330 --> 00:06:02.290

00:06:02.290 --> 00:06:05.464

00:06:05.464 --> 00:06:08.908
So you can go and take the test there,

60 questions, 90 minutes, multiple choice,

107
00:06:14.680 --> 00:06:17.215
So what is the stuff that we need to know?

108
00:06:17.215 --> 00:06:20.430
Well the two exams
are a little bit different.

109
00:06:20.430 --> 00:06:25.890
We've got the LX0-101,
that's the first exam, and

110
00:06:25.890 --> 00:06:30.250
it covers what I consider to be
the introductory information.

111
00:06:30.250 --> 00:06:32.930
Now if you've never
worked with Linux before,

112
00:06:32.930 --> 00:06:34.670
some of this is pretty challenging.

113
00:06:34.670 --> 00:06:36.200
But if you've got experience with Linux,

114
00:06:36.200 --> 00:06:39.800
if you've been running it on your desktop
or as a server for years and years.

115
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:44.370
This one's actually the easier of the two
exams because it's covering things like

116
00:06:44.370 --> 00:06:46.660

117
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:51.935

to get it updated to make sure that you're

118
00:06:51.935 --> 00:06:57.110
doing hot fixes and security updates, it's
covering basic command line exercises.

119
00:06:57.110 --> 00:06:59.250
Now that's really important.

120
00:06:59.250 --> 00:07:03.000
A lot of people say, well,
I've been running Linux for five years and

121
00:07:03.000 --> 00:07:05.380
I use Ubuntu and I love it, right?

122
00:07:05.380 --> 00:07:08.140
And then I say okay how often do you drop

123
00:07:08.140 --> 00:07:10.550

actually run command line?

124

I do it all through the GUI.

125
00:07:13.890 --> 00:07:16.340
Well that's a recipe for disaster, right?

126
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:18.640
Because the GUI differs so

127
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:24.150
much from distro to distro, it's hard
to learn one way that works everywhere.

128
00:07:24.150 --> 00:07:27.305
And if you're on a server you
shouldn't have a GUI at all.

129
00:07:27.305 --> 00:07:32.750
Right, so the exam is almost
entirely based on command line.

130
00:07:32.750 --> 00:07:36.957
Cuz when you learn something that way,
when you learn it command line style,

131
00:07:36.957 --> 00:07:39.442
you can use it on any
GNU Linux distribution.

132
00:07:39.442 --> 00:07:44.850
And so that really makes life easy,
standard, compliant, right?

133
00:07:44.850 --> 00:07:47.670
So if you've got a lot of graphical
user interface experience,

134
00:07:47.670 --> 00:07:50.700
that will help you a little bit on
the second exam, but on the first exam,

135
00:07:50.700 --> 00:07:52.780
you're gonna be dead in the water,
cuz it's almost all command line.

136
00:07:52.780 --> 00:07:56.840
So we tackle that,
the GNU and Unix commands.

137
00:07:56.840 --> 00:08:00.490
We also take a look at how
hardware devices are accessed,

138
00:08:00.490 --> 00:08:05.390
how the file systems work, and the file
hierarchy, how the folders are arranged.

139
00:08:05.390 --> 00:08:08.190
And again, if you've been
working with Unix or Linux for

140
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:12.370
a while, then that's second
nature by now more than likely.

141
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:14.100
But, if you're brand new to this,

142
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:17.690
it's really different than a lot of other
operating systems that are out there.

143
00:08:17.690 --> 00:08:20.970
If you've got a lot of Windows experience,
this stuff will blow your mind,

144
00:08:20.970 --> 00:08:22.690
because it's really different,

145
00:08:22.690 --> 00:08:27.230
that hardware devices reference as files,
not as objects.

146
00:08:27.230 --> 00:08:30.621
If you're used to OSX and Mac OS,

147
00:08:30.621 --> 00:08:34.070
Mac OS is running on top of BSD so
you might think they're similar.

148
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:38.610
But Apple is tweaked with that file system
so much that directories and paths and

149
00:08:38.610 --> 00:08:42.250
stuff are just not the same
as we see in the Linux world.

150
00:08:42.250 --> 00:08:45.130
So getting used to this can be
a little challenging, right, so

151
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:46.270
definitely keep that in mind.

152
00:08:47.810 --> 00:08:50.030
So that's kind of what you
expect to see on the first exam.

153
00:08:50.030 --> 00:08:56.490
Notice that the bulk of it, 43% of that
exam, is from the command line, right.

154
00:08:56.490 --> 00:09:02.250
GNU and Unix, or GNU, sometimes called
New, in Unix command line utility.

155
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:05.120
So, you've really got to
spend some time on that.

156
00:09:05.120 --> 00:09:09.750
If you are, [LAUGH] if you're
30 plus years old and you cut

157
00:09:09.750 --> 00:09:14.650
your teeth on DOS and Windows 3.1, then
it's not a big challenge to pick that up.

158
00:09:14.650 --> 00:09:19.940
But if you're 20 years old and just out
of high school and you grew up with

159
00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:24.130
Windows XP and stuff, you might not
have used the command line very much.

160
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:27.389
And even if you've been in
the Linux world for 10,

161
00:09:27.389 --> 00:09:30.990
20 years, you might be GUI-heavy and
not command line-heavy.

162
00:09:30.990 --> 00:09:34.110
So, we do need to make sure we focus
in on that and spend some time.

163
00:09:34.110 --> 00:09:36.480
That's what you're gonna
see on the first exam.

164
00:09:36.480 --> 00:09:38.920
So basic operational skills and really,

165
00:09:38.920 --> 00:09:43.120
everything that you learn in this exam
should apply to any Linux distribution

166
00:09:43.120 --> 00:09:46.982
that you're running unless it's some
crazy completely whacked out one.

167
00:09:46.982 --> 00:09:49.269
[LAUGH] But
most of them will work just like this.

168
00:09:50.660 --> 00:09:51.327
All right,

169
00:09:51.327 --> 00:09:55.270
now each of these topics are broken
down into quite a bit of sub topics.

170
00:09:55.270 --> 00:09:58.140
You'll see some of the different things
that it goes into and we'll go over all

171
00:09:58.140 --> 00:10:01.320
these during the actual show so I don't
want to bore us to death with them now.

172
00:10:01.320 --> 00:10:03.280
But lets take a look at that second exam.

173
00:10:03.280 --> 00:10:06.800
The other exam is the LX0-102,

174
00:10:06.800 --> 00:10:11.840
this guy right here, and it breaks
things down a little bit differently.

175
00:10:11.840 --> 00:10:15.860
You'll see where we tackle Shells,
Scripting and Data Management, all right?

176
00:10:17.230 --> 00:10:20.890
In my opinion, scripting is one of
the most useful things that you can learn,

177
00:10:20.890 --> 00:10:22.920
because you don't wanna
run the same task over and

178
00:10:22.920 --> 00:10:26.300
over again if you can automate it, and
scripting is all about automating it.

179
00:10:26.300 --> 00:10:27.830
So we're gonna get
a chance to see that and

180
00:10:27.830 --> 00:10:30.770
as an administrator that's something
we really do benefit from.

181
00:10:30.770 --> 00:10:35.340
We'll see user interfaces and desktops,
we're gonna talk about several of

182
00:10:35.340 --> 00:10:39.930
the different graphical user interfaces
available because you've got Gnome and

183
00:10:39.930 --> 00:10:44.665
KDE, you've got Enlightenment,
I think ten people run that.

184
00:10:44.665 --> 00:10:46.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> Xfce, which is one of my favorites,

185
00:10:46.870 --> 00:10:49.940
so there's several different user
interfaces that are out there,

186
00:10:49.940 --> 00:10:52.810
we'll take a look at each of them and
some of the ins and outs.

187
00:10:52.810 --> 00:10:57.565
But notice, user interfaces and
desktops, only 8%,

188
00:10:57.565 --> 00:11:02.665
very small part of that exam because
it's just not standard between systems.

189
00:11:02.665 --> 00:11:06.435
We'll see general administrative tasks,
things like creating user accounts,

190
00:11:06.435 --> 00:11:09.600
changing file permissions,
stuff like that.

191
00:11:09.600 --> 00:11:14.200
Essential system services, we'll take a
look at web servers and e-mail servers and

192
00:11:14.200 --> 00:11:16.520
some of the things that we typically run.

193
00:11:16.520 --> 00:11:20.290
We'll definitely spend some time on SSH
cuz that's such an important service and

194
00:11:20.290 --> 00:11:24.290
a few of the other services that we
may use as a part of running Linux.

195
00:11:25.300 --> 00:11:27.890
We've got networking fundamentals.

196
00:11:27.890 --> 00:11:31.800
So configuring our network adapter, some
of the neat features we have in Linux,

197
00:11:31.800 --> 00:11:35.560
IPv4 and IPv6 support,
some of the different things there.

198
00:11:35.560 --> 00:11:39.830
As well as NFS, the network file system,
we’ll cover it in there too.

199
00:11:39.830 --> 00:11:43.250
And then lastly, security,
it’s last but not least.

200
00:11:43.250 --> 00:11:46.370
In a very literal sense,
security is really important to us.

201
00:11:46.370 --> 00:11:50.710
A lot of us are using Linux as a server
operating system and in that scenario,

202
00:11:50.710 --> 00:11:53.970
security's really important so
we need to take a look at that.

203
00:11:53.970 --> 00:11:57.930
We're gonna take a look at configuring
software firewalls under Linux, as well as

204
00:11:57.930 --> 00:12:01.990
other processes like just staying up to
date that are really, really important.

205
00:12:03.020 --> 00:12:05.730
So, the first exam is based on

206
00:12:05.730 --> 00:12:09.170
fundamentals that every Linux
administrator should have.

207
00:12:09.170 --> 00:12:12.660
The second exam is based
more on practical skills,

208
00:12:12.660 --> 00:12:15.570
things we're gonna do on
an ongoing day-to-day basis.

209
00:12:15.570 --> 00:12:19.160
So they're really two neat

1942
01:38:50.209 --> 01:38:54.319
So when I do a new install,
these are the first two commands I run.

1943
01:38:54.319 --> 01:38:57.976
App-get update followed
by app-get upgrade.

1944
01:38:57.976 --> 01:39:02.050
So if I were to run that,
that would upgrade them all and

1945
01:39:02.050 --> 01:39:03.858
things would be great.

1946
01:39:03.858 --> 01:39:08.380
Well, there are a few other things we
needed to be aware of before I run this.

1947
01:39:08.380 --> 01:39:11.010
There's actually two variations
of the upgrade command.

1948
01:39:11.010 --> 01:39:14.370
App-get upgrade, we'll look for

1949
01:39:14.370 --> 01:39:20.090
individual packages and
upgrade them and it will never

1950
01:39:20.090 --> 01:39:25.340
under any circumstances remove a package
that you've already got installed.

1951
01:39:25.340 --> 01:39:28.271
Now you might ask yourself,
why would we do that?

1952
01:39:28.271 --> 01:39:29.490
Why would we remove one?

1953
01:39:29.490 --> 01:39:33.634
Well a lot of times one package
will depend on another package,

1954
01:39:33.634 --> 01:39:36.850
which may in turn depend
on another one and so on.

1955
01:39:36.850 --> 01:39:37.670
You have these dependencies,

1956
01:39:37.670 --> 01:39:43.050
and when you upgrade one the dependency
on that other package might go away.

1957
01:39:43.050 --> 01:39:46.950
We don't need it anymore, and so you could
technically remove that other package.

1958
01:39:46.950 --> 01:39:47.920
You don't need it anymore.

1959
01:39:48.960 --> 01:39:51.720
Well when you do apt-get upgrade,
it doesn't do that.

1960
01:39:51.720 --> 01:39:54.030
It never removes a package.

1961
01:39:54.030 --> 01:39:56.310
If you wanted to go ahead and
remove packages,

1962
01:39:56.310 --> 01:39:58.690
to actually just bring it current and
remove things.

1963
01:39:58.690 --> 01:39:59.330
Well first off,

1964
01:39:59.330 --> 01:40:01.830
you need to know what you're doing
cuz you run the risk of breaking

1965
01:40:01.830 --> 01:40:04.090
other software that might
be dependent on it.

1966
01:40:04.090 --> 01:40:07.650
But you can modify this
command slightly and say,

1967
01:40:07.650 --> 01:40:12.020
apt-get dist-upgrade or
distribution upgrade.

1968
01:40:12.020 --> 01:40:16.572
That's going to update your packages and
any dependencies that have been remove,

1969
01:40:16.572 --> 01:40:19.640
it will remove those packages and
get them out of there.

1970
01:40:19.640 --> 01:40:22.759
So if you stayed on the straight and
narrow with installing your packages and

1971
01:40:22.759 --> 01:40:26.360
they have all come from the BM library,
that's perfectly safe to do.

1972
01:40:26.360 --> 01:40:30.900
But if you've installed third
party applications not from the BM

1973
01:40:30.900 --> 01:40:36.570
distribution library, then this
could break some of your software.

1974
01:40:36.570 --> 01:40:39.560
So you just need to evaluate
what's right for your environment.

1975
01:40:39.560 --> 01:40:43.900
Because I just did a clean install,
either command will work fine for me.

1976
01:40:43.900 --> 01:40:45.980
So I could run either one and
it would do the full upgrade.

1977
01:40:47.370 --> 01:40:51.175
The other thing is,
I don't have to update the whole OS,

1978
01:40:51.175 --> 01:40:55.074
I could update just a very
particular package if I wanted.

1979
01:40:55.074 --> 01:40:58.633
If there was one package in
particular that I wanted to update,

1980
01:40:58.633 --> 01:41:02.560
I could reach out and check for
updates on it and do the update.

1981
01:41:02.560 --> 01:41:07.570
So for example, I could say, app-get and

1982
01:41:09.060 --> 01:41:11.930
install, and
then a particular package name.

01:41:11.930 --> 01:41:13.610
If I wanted to have something.

01:41:20.719 --> 01:41:21.740
it's not here.

1988
01:41:21.740 --> 01:41:29.260
I can say at-get install vim, and it'll
reach out and it'll find that package.

01:41:29.260 --> 01:41:32.090
So it found one, the vim runtime.

1990
01:41:32.090 --> 01:41:34.170

01:41:47.833 --> 01:41:50.573

01:41:55.045 --> 01:41:57.739
We'll give that just a second.

1997

So it's gonna find it,
it's there on the DVD.

1998
01:42:02.848 --> 01:42:04.530
I just didn't install it and
it's gonna pull it in.

1999
01:42:04.530 --> 01:42:08.697
Now notice when it goes to install it,
it's actually installing several different

2000
01:42:08.697 --> 01:42:12.349
things not just vim, and that's
because vim depends on other packages.

2001
01:42:12.349 --> 01:42:18.366
So it's getting them installing it and
I should now have vim, and I sure do.

2002
01:42:18.366 --> 01:42:23.013
So to install one package,
we can do that then we can do app-get,

2003
01:42:23.013 --> 01:42:25.470
I probably need to redo my update.

2004
01:42:25.470 --> 01:42:33.420
And then we can say, app-get upgrade vim.

2005
01:42:33.420 --> 01:42:36.530
Don't upgrade everything,
just upgrade vim.

2006
01:42:36.530 --> 01:42:40.541
And if any of the dependencies go away,
leave them in place or I could say,

2007
01:42:40.541 --> 01:42:41.523
dist-upgrade.

2008
01:42:41.523 --> 01:42:44.480
And now if any of the dependencies
are gone it'll remove them.

2009
01:42:44.480 --> 01:42:46.710
So we can get really specific like that,

2010
01:42:46.710 --> 01:42:51.870
we can tell it how we cant to go
about that, I'll go the safer way.

2011
01:42:51.870 --> 01:42:56.059
And it will look, and there's no updates
available, it's running the latest one.

2012
01:42:56.059 --> 01:43:00.790
So 0 remove, 0 upgraded,
it didn't have to do anything.

2013
01:43:01.950 --> 01:43:06.570
So you may see that when you do the big
upgrade, when you upgrade everything.

2014
01:43:06.570 --> 01:43:11.050
So if I do the full dist-upgrade
like that and run it,

2015
01:43:11.050 --> 01:43:15.140
I'm gonna find that everything is current
cuz I'm pulling from my DVD here.

2016
01:43:15.140 --> 01:43:18.960
So everything is current, doesn't need to
find anything special and it's just done.

2017
01:43:21.020 --> 01:43:24.370
The other thing is we can
remove packages with apt-get.

2018
01:43:24.370 --> 01:43:26.835
So to remove packages you just say,

2019
01:43:26.835 --> 01:43:31.710
apt-get remove and then the name of
the package that you want to remove.

2020
01:43:31.710 --> 01:43:34.871
So I can remove them, if I decide
that I don't actually want it, and

2021
01:43:34.871 --> 01:43:36.432
then it's gonna remove it here.

2022
01:43:36.432 --> 01:43:38.808
It will tell me that, I'll say, yes.

2023
01:43:38.808 --> 01:43:41.525
And that removes it, and it's gone.

2024
01:43:41.525 --> 01:43:43.510
So pretty straightforward there.

2025
01:43:43.510 --> 01:43:47.624
Whenever you install a package, it
downloads the package from the server or

2026
01:43:47.624 --> 01:43:49.755
DVD, wherever you're loading from.

2027
01:43:49.755 --> 01:43:52.643
And once it's got that,
once it's got it downloaded,

2028
01:43:52.643 --> 01:43:56.790
it then installs it and
copies the files wherever it wants to go.

2029
01:43:56.790 --> 01:43:59.040
It saves those package files though.

2030
01:43:59.040 --> 01:44:01.778
So it actually caches those and
retains a copy.

2031
01:44:01.778 --> 01:44:05.060
If you wanna get rid of those,
you can use the purge modifier.

2032
01:44:06.540 --> 01:44:13.270
So you can say at-get--purge remove vim.

2033
01:44:13.270 --> 01:44:16.170
And now, when it removes vim,
the package which I've already removed it,

2034
01:44:16.170 --> 01:44:19.710
but when it removes it, it not only
removes the installed files, but

2035
01:44:19.710 --> 01:44:22.740
it removes the cached
copy of the package also.

2036
01:44:22.740 --> 01:44:26.700
So if you wanna completely get rid of it,
you just add that purge modifier to it.

2037
01:44:26.700 --> 01:44:31.758
Now, we don't have it so

2038
01:44:31.758 --> 01:44:34.358

01:44:43.100 --> 01:44:43.750
So I'll go ahead and

01:44:43.750 --> 01:44:48.060
knock that one out, by just modifying

2044
01:44:48.060 --> 01:44:52.261
And we'll get that one out of there and
there it goes.

2045
01:44:52.261 --> 01:44:56.849
Now I've fully removed it, it's out of the
system, and the cache package is gone too,

2046
01:44:56.849 --> 01:44:57.471
all right.

2047
01:44:57.471 --> 01:45:00.246
So apt-get, pretty straight forward.

2048
01:45:00.246 --> 01:45:04.056
The main two commands we
want are apt-get update,

2049
01:45:04.056 --> 01:45:08.753
followed by app-get upgrade or
app-getdisc-upgrade those

2050
01:45:08.753 --> 01:45:13.550
are the main ones that we have for
doing our updates, all right.

2051
01:45:13.550 --> 01:45:16.960
Now, app get, that's the main one,
that's the one that we're gonna use,

2052
01:45:16.960 --> 01:45:20.133
that's the one that we're going to
see the most commonly, all right.

2053
01:45:20.133 --> 01:45:24.365
But I also mention there's
the older utility, dpkg,

2054
01:45:24.365 --> 01:45:28.180

01:45:28.180 --> 01:45:30.200
And you can still use it,

2056
01:45:30.200 --> 01:45:33.430
They do still update it though, so you
could actually choose to use this instead

2057
01:45:33.430 --> 01:45:36.880
of the other one if you wanted and
you'd be perfectly fine, all right?

2058
01:45:36.880 --> 01:45:40.613
So the way it works is very, very similar,
the syntax is not much different.

2059
01:45:40.613 --> 01:45:44.805
If you run, for example, dpkg -l,
that's how you get a list of whatever

2060
01:45:44.805 --> 01:45:47.509
packages you have installed
on your system, so

2061
01:45:47.509 --> 01:45:50.435
it just outputs this

2062
01:45:50.435 --> 01:45:55.574
And I can see, I missed a few,

01:45:55.574 --> 01:46:00.123
so I've got a few installed that
It didn't show me a minute ago,

01:46:00.123 --> 01:46:04.130
that's interesting, so

01:46:04.130 --> 01:46:08.240
If I do dpkg -l in a specific package,

2066
01:46:08.240 --> 01:46:12.990
like whois, it'll give me information
on that one particular package.

2067
01:46:12.990 --> 01:46:15.900
What it's called,
what version it is and so on.

2068
01:46:15.900 --> 01:46:18.202
So, you can start to extract information.

2069
01:46:18.202 --> 01:46:20.947
Another neat little command we have,

2070
01:46:20.947 --> 01:46:24.560
is if you're looking at
a file on your hard drive.

2071
01:46:24.560 --> 01:46:28.447
So you've been kinda messing
around on your hard drive and

2072
01:46:28.447 --> 01:46:31.619
there is some file and
you just don't know where

01:46:31.619 --> 01:46:35.768
that file came from like this

01:46:35.768 --> 01:46:39.808
And I wanna know who it is created

01:46:39.808 --> 01:46:44.993
Well, you can use dpkj-s and
specify a file and

01:46:44.993 --> 01:46:49.409
so I will specify that file right there.

01:46:49.409 --> 01:46:53.840
And it will take a look at it and

01:46:53.840 --> 01:46:58.060

01:46:58.060 --> 01:47:00.820
That's very useful if you're trying

01:47:12.560 --> 01:47:15.230

If I remove it,

you come across a file and

1344
01:09:46.970 --> 01:09:51.110
you're like what made this
miniserve.error file?

1345
01:09:51.110 --> 01:09:52.470
I don't understand.

1346
01:09:52.470 --> 01:09:57.730
We can do rpm-qf,
which is basically querying this file.

1347
01:09:57.730 --> 01:10:02.700
And I can tell it to take a look at
miniserve.error and it will look at it and

1348
01:10:02.700 --> 01:10:06.290
show what package was responsible for
creating that.

1349
01:10:06.290 --> 01:10:07.820
And apparently, I picked a bad example,

1350
01:10:07.820 --> 01:10:10.390
cuz it's saying it's not
owned by any package.

1351
01:10:10.390 --> 01:10:13.560
So it must be a temporary file then.

1352
01:10:13.560 --> 01:10:15.650
So we could try something else,

1353
01:10:15.650 --> 01:10:19.790
although I imagine it's gonna do the same
thing on these other ones, isn't it?

1354
01:10:19.790 --> 01:10:22.190
Let's try the PID file,
that's a process file.

1355
01:10:22.190 --> 01:10:25.370
Well yeah, all right, so it's going
to try the whole directory I suppose.

1356
01:10:28.650 --> 01:10:31.680
And it found, all right, so
apparently it didn't register.

1357
01:10:31.680 --> 01:10:36.480
This comes down to whoever built this
package, so when the webmin guys built it

1358
01:10:36.480 --> 01:10:39.360
they just didn't put in that
listing to update the database, so

1359
01:10:39.360 --> 01:10:40.750
it doesn't have a record of it.

1360
01:10:40.750 --> 01:10:43.060
Let's pick something else,
something that is in here.

1361
01:10:44.230 --> 01:10:47.901
So I'll take, well vimrc, right?

1362
01:10:47.901 --> 01:10:49.770
I think I did that one in the Debian show.

1363
01:10:49.770 --> 01:10:57.670
So I could do rpm -qf /etc/ vimrc,
all right?

1364
01:10:57.670 --> 01:11:02.050
And it'll query that, and it'll show
that it belongs to vimcommon, and

1365
01:11:02.050 --> 01:11:04.940
that its current version is 7.2,
blah, blah blah, right?

1366
01:11:04.940 --> 01:11:09.220
So we can query who it is that's
responsible for that file, all right.

1367
01:11:09.220 --> 01:11:11.150
What other ones do I have here on my list?

1368
01:11:11.150 --> 01:11:14.420
Verifying packages, all right.

1369
01:11:14.420 --> 01:11:17.360
It's possible that you installed
a package and when you installed it,

1370
01:11:17.360 --> 01:11:20.010
there's a lot of files
inside of that package.

1371
01:11:20.010 --> 01:11:22.900
And so when you installed it,
all those files got copied out of there.

1372
01:11:22.900 --> 01:11:26.630
Well, what if somebody went and
deleted one of those files?

1373
01:11:26.630 --> 01:11:29.750
You don't necessarily know that,
the package may have contained 100 files,

1374
01:11:29.750 --> 01:11:30.530
now there's 99 of them.

1375
01:11:30.530 --> 01:11:32.800
How do you know that one is missing?

1376
01:11:32.800 --> 01:11:35.653
Well we have a nice little
verification that we can run.

1377
01:11:35.653 --> 01:11:41.307
You can run rpm -Va.

1378
01:11:41.307 --> 01:11:45.136
And that will validate or
verify all of your packages and

1379
01:11:45.136 --> 01:11:47.588
look to see if anything is missing.

1380
01:11:47.588 --> 01:11:50.688
And when you run that,
it can be a lot, right?

1381
01:11:50.688 --> 01:11:53.568
So we usually shrink that down a bit.

1382
01:11:53.568 --> 01:11:55.768
We can say -Vp.

1383
01:11:55.768 --> 01:11:59.668
>> And I can say let's go ahead and
validate Vim.

1384
01:11:59.668 --> 01:12:00.640
All right.

1385
01:12:00.640 --> 01:12:01.790
And, shoot.

1386
01:12:01.790 --> 01:12:03.580
It has to be in RPM that
I've got sitting here.

1387
01:12:03.580 --> 01:12:04.930
So, I'll do WebMin.

1388
01:12:04.930 --> 01:12:08.758
So I'll do RPM dash Vp Webmin.

1389
01:12:08.758 --> 01:12:11.100
That one, all right.

1390
01:12:11.100 --> 01:12:13.030
And so, it's gonna take a look at it and

1391
01:12:13.030 --> 01:12:15.155
it's gonna be angry cuz I have no key,
wonderful.

1392
01:12:15.155 --> 01:12:17.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's gonna validate it and look.

1393
01:12:17.740 --> 01:12:20.750
And if there were any missing files,
it would tell me.

1394
01:12:20.750 --> 01:12:23.230
It would give me a list of
the files that were missing.

1395
01:12:23.230 --> 01:12:24.120
In my case,

1396
01:12:24.120 --> 01:12:27.060
they just gave me a key warning
because I haven't installed their key.

1397
01:12:27.060 --> 01:12:29.570
But otherwise,
it didn't report any missing files.

1398
01:12:29.570 --> 01:12:30.900
So it looks like I'm in good shape.

1399
01:12:30.900 --> 01:12:31.690
All right.

1400
01:12:31.690 --> 01:12:33.830
Now, what if I were to
remove that package, right?

1401
01:12:33.830 --> 01:12:34.900
If I were to get rid of it.

1402
01:12:36.930 --> 01:12:38.506
Let's see, what is that syntax?

1403
01:12:38.506 --> 01:12:41.635
It is Not yum.

1404
01:12:41.635 --> 01:12:42.996
Well, I could use yum, I suppose.

1405
01:12:47.696 --> 01:12:49.235
And get rid of it.

1406
01:12:49.235 --> 01:12:50.915
So, I'm deleting it with
a different command.

1407
01:12:50.915 --> 01:12:54.455
I'm deleting it with yum,
which is not happy about it.

1408
01:12:54.455 --> 01:12:57.290
But, so, I'm just gonna remove that
out of there and get it out of place.

1409
01:12:57.290 --> 01:13:02.230
And now, when I go and rerun that verify,
so, I'm gonna verify this package.

1410
01:13:02.230 --> 01:13:05.470
When I run it,
look at that giant list of missing files.

1411
01:13:05.470 --> 01:13:09.430
So, it just let me know that all these
files should be there, and their missing.

1412
01:13:09.430 --> 01:13:12.610
So, great way to quickly test to make
sure that the package is still intact,

1413
01:13:12.610 --> 01:13:14.462
that all the files
are where they should be.

1414
01:13:17.010 --> 01:13:17.724
All right.

1415
01:13:17.724 --> 01:13:20.498
And you can remove a package with RPM,
also.

1416
01:13:20.498 --> 01:13:24.298
I just don't remember I
don't remember the syntax.

1417
01:13:24.298 --> 01:13:27.378
Is it, gee.

1418
01:13:31.706 --> 01:13:33.670
No, it does not want to feed into that,
does it?

1419
01:13:33.670 --> 01:13:36.950
>> No.
>> I wanna say it's dash r to remove.

1420
01:13:36.950 --> 01:13:42.790
But No, I guess it isn't.

1421
01:13:42.790 --> 01:13:44.324
All right.
Well, there is a tag for it,

1422
01:13:44.324 --> 01:13:45.700
I just don't seem to remember it.

1423
01:13:45.700 --> 01:13:48.820
But, basically,
you've got a suite of utilities here.

1424
01:13:48.820 --> 01:13:51.450
Just my rule of thumb,
if you're connected to the Internet,

1425
01:13:51.450 --> 01:13:54.040
you're using internet repositories,
Yum is the way to go.

1426
01:13:54.040 --> 01:13:56.640
Although, it can be used for
local stuff, too.

1427
01:13:56.640 --> 01:13:58.820
RPM is great for offline servicing.

1428
01:13:58.820 --> 01:13:59.795
We can use it for installing.

1429
01:13:59.795 --> 01:14:03.660
Yum does dependency checking and
is very robust.

1430
01:14:03.660 --> 01:14:08.592
RPM doesn't do dependency checking and
is very, very streamlined, you know?

1431
01:14:08.592 --> 01:14:10.920
So, Yum is gonna be our go to guy.

1432
01:14:10.920 --> 01:14:12.970
That's the one we're gonna
work with most of the time.

1433
01:14:12.970 --> 01:14:17.980
You'll fire up a new operating system,
and you'll say yum-y update,

1434
01:14:17.980 --> 01:14:20.900
that says check for updates and
go ahead and apply them.

1435
01:14:20.900 --> 01:14:22.410
Just go ahead and do it.

1436
01:14:22.410 --> 01:14:25.840
And when you run that, it reaches out and
it immediately starts to update.

1437
01:14:25.840 --> 01:14:27.130
So, here it goes and grabs.

1438
01:14:27.130 --> 01:14:29.970
So, if this is a brand new system,
there's no reason not to do this.

1439
01:14:29.970 --> 01:14:33.550
Now, after this system is in production,
it changes a little.

1440
01:14:33.550 --> 01:14:35.070
Then, you run Yum update, and

1441
01:14:35.070 --> 01:14:37.970
you look through the list and you make
sure everything's tested and okay.

1442
01:14:37.970 --> 01:14:39.740
You don't just blindly apply them.

1443
01:14:39.740 --> 01:14:41.777
But on a brand new install,
we oftentimes do.

1444
01:14:43.497 --> 01:14:46.170
All right.

1445
01:14:46.170 --> 01:14:48.210
I think that's pretty much all I've got.

1446
01:14:48.210 --> 01:14:51.870
The only other thing I've
got is just like on Debian,

1447
01:14:51.870 --> 01:14:56.550
when we install a package sent OS and
redhat, they retain a copy

1448
01:14:56.550 --> 01:15:01.210
of that package on the drive just in case
we need it for some reason or another.

1449
01:15:01.210 --> 01:15:06.852
So, if we need to get that cleaned up,
if we're trying to recover space,

1450
01:15:06.852 --> 01:15:10.043
there is a clean operator that we can use.

1451
01:15:10.043 --> 01:15:15.910
So, you can say, it's Yum clean all,
and that'll go ahead and remove that.

1452
01:15:15.910 --> 01:15:18.290
It's not one I use very often,
I had to look at my notes.

1453
01:15:18.290 --> 01:15:21.540
Cuz hard drive space isn't
a problem like it used to be, so

1454
01:15:21.540 --> 01:15:23.040
we're not normally worried about it.

1455
01:15:23.040 --> 01:15:26.220
But if you're trying to clean that stuff
up, you can run Yum Clean All, and

1456
01:15:26.220 --> 01:15:27.082
it'll knock it out.

1457
01:15:27.082 --> 01:15:29.153
That's gonna take a little while to run,
isn't it?

1458
01:15:34.345 --> 01:15:37.680
Well, you know what I could do,
I could, where's my GUI install?

1459
01:15:37.680 --> 01:15:38.390
This one.

1460
01:15:38.390 --> 01:15:39.700
We'll jump over here and do it.

1461
01:15:39.700 --> 01:15:42.580
So, here I am on this one,
and I can say Yum Clean All.

1462
01:15:42.580 --> 01:15:43.620
I'm not root.

1463
01:15:43.620 --> 01:15:44.770
It'll be mad about that, won't it?

1464
01:15:47.150 --> 01:15:48.800
There.
Yum Clean All.

1465
01:15:48.800 --> 01:15:50.130
And what it's gonna do,
it's gonna look for

1466
01:15:50.130 --> 01:15:53.310
any leftover package files that we don't
need, and it's gonna clean them out.

1467
01:15:53.310 --> 01:15:55.360
So, see how it says
cleaning up everything?

1468
01:15:55.360 --> 01:15:57.500
Just knocking out anything we don't need.

1469
01:15:57.500 --> 01:16:02.770
And that's pretty handy,
cuz if I do Yum install vim,

1470
01:16:02.770 --> 01:16:05.760
it's gonna go through and
install vim and its dependencies.

1471
01:16:05.760 --> 01:16:09.160
And then, if I uninstall it, sure,
it removes the files from VIM, but

1472
01:16:09.160 --> 01:16:12.600
it leaves the package file sitting there,
so that's what it would remove.

1473
01:16:12.600 --> 01:16:17.756
Apparently, I all ready have VIM,
so if I knock it out.

1474
01:16:20.518 --> 01:16:21.470
There we go.

1475
01:16:21.470 --> 01:16:23.730
So, I removed it, but
the package is still there.

1476
01:16:23.730 --> 01:16:27.090
And it's not until I do Yum Clean All that
it's gonna go through and wipe it out.

1477
01:16:27.090 --> 01:16:29.460
And so, now,
it's actually wiped out that package.

1478
01:16:29.460 --> 01:16:30.160
All right.

1479
01:16:30.160 --> 01:16:30.920
That's really about it.

1480
01:16:30.920 --> 01:16:32.030
It's pretty straightforward.

1481
01:16:32.030 --> 01:16:35.100
The commands are fairly intuitive,
and you might have noticed

1482
01:16:35.100 --> 01:16:38.950
the commands between app get and
yum are actually very similar.

1483
01:16:38.950 --> 01:16:40.050
>> Right.
>> And so, oftentimes,

1484
01:16:40.050 --> 01:16:43.150
it's just a matter of swapping out
AppGet for Yum and vice versa,

1485
01:16:43.150 --> 01:16:44.835
and that'll knock it out.

1486
01:16:44.835 --> 01:16:50.760
But on the exam you may see some of
the fringe utilities like RPM and DPKG.

1487
01:16:50.760 --> 01:16:52.400
One other tool worth mentioning.

1488
01:16:52.400 --> 01:16:54.950
The packages themselves, the RPMs,

1489
01:16:54.950 --> 01:16:59.910
they're not just like zipped up files
that you can dearchive really easily.

1490
01:16:59.910 --> 01:17:02.800
The files themselves
are compiled in a certain way.

1491
01:17:02.800 --> 01:17:06.690
And so, if you need to extract
individual files from there,

1492
01:17:06.690 --> 01:17:10.490
there's another utility called rpm2cio.

1493
01:17:10.490 --> 01:17:15.646
And what it does is it lets you
convert the RPM file into a CPIO

1494
01:17:15.646 --> 01:17:20.600
file which will let you copy and
get content from inside of it.

1495
01:17:20.600 --> 01:17:23.040
It might show up on the exam, not always.

1496
01:17:23.040 --> 01:17:25.360
But RPM to CPIO.

1497
01:17:25.360 --> 01:17:27.600
And basically, you point it at a package.

1498
01:17:27.600 --> 01:17:29.120
I didn't.
I was just trying to get the help file,

1499
01:17:29.120 --> 01:17:31.030
which apparently it
doesn't want to bring up.

1500
01:17:31.030 --> 01:17:34.090
But you just point it to a package,
and it'll do the conversion to it.

1501
01:17:34.090 --> 01:17:37.481
There's not much that you even
provide it with as far as input.

1502
01:17:41.878 --> 01:17:42.890
There we go.

1503
01:17:42.890 --> 01:17:46.100
So, there it's doing just the straight
out dump of that information.

1504
01:17:46.100 --> 01:17:47.790
I should have piped
that into another file.

1505
01:17:47.790 --> 01:17:50.530
Let me do that.

1506
01:17:50.530 --> 01:17:56.220
So, I will pipe that into,
I'll just call it webmn.cpio.

1507
01:17:56.220 --> 01:18:00.830
And when you do that,
now you've got a CPIO file.

1508
01:18:00.830 --> 01:18:03.390
You'll see it's basically like D archive,
drpm.

1509
01:18:03.390 --> 01:18:08.800
And now, I can reach into it and
grab content out of it as I need.

1510
01:18:08.800 --> 01:18:14.650
RPM to CPIO Doesn't have
much of a help file.

1511
01:18:14.650 --> 01:18:18.580
You'll see right there, you just specify
the package and that's about it.

1512
01:18:18.580 --> 01:18:21.700
But there are other utilities you
can use to reach in for CPIO.

1513
01:18:21.700 --> 01:18:23.980
I don't think I have
any of those installed.

1514
01:18:23.980 --> 01:18:24.970
I do.

1515
01:18:24.970 --> 01:18:26.879
So, if we take a look at CPIO,

1516
01:18:26.879 --> 01:18:30.450
you'll see some of the different
things that it's got.

1517
01:18:30.450 --> 01:18:34.340
But you've got in there where
you can specify the file and

1518
01:18:34.340 --> 01:18:36.660
what you're trying to
grab from inside of it.

1519
01:18:36.660 --> 01:18:38.870
And it can reach inside of that and
pull out individual files.

1520
01:18:38.870 --> 01:18:42.798
So, if you ever need to extract just one
file from an rpm, there's utilities for

1521
01:18:42.798 --> 01:18:44.060
that, all right?

1522
01:18:44.060 --> 01:18:45.410
Normally, you don't have to do that.

1523
01:18:45.410 --> 01:18:49.190
If you think something's damaged, you just
reinstall the package, and off you go.

1524
01:18:49.190 --> 01:18:50.570
So, that's normally my approach, at least.

1525
01:18:52.250 --> 01:18:52.790
All right.
Well,

1526
01:18:52.790 --> 01:18:54.770
that's probably a pretty good spot for
us to wrap up.

1527
01:18:54.770 --> 01:18:57.250
Ronnie, can you think of anything
else we should throw out there?

1528
01:18:57.250 --> 01:18:58.100
>> Nope, not really, yeah.

1529
01:18:58.100 --> 01:18:59.010
>> All right.

1530
01:18:59.010 --> 01:19:01.850
Well, like I said,
I'm gonna post my little notes,

1531
01:19:01.850 --> 01:19:03.770
the various command that
we talked about today.

1532
01:19:03.770 --> 01:19:06.540
So, I'll post those with the videos so
you can see them.

1533
01:19:06.540 --> 01:19:09.980
But otherwise,
that's getting it installed now.

1534
01:19:09.980 --> 01:19:12.640
For the rest of this show,
not this episode, but

1535
01:19:12.640 --> 01:19:15.480
the entire show,
we're gonna be working in CentOS.

1536
01:19:15.480 --> 01:19:17.440
So, this is gonna be the distribution
we're gonna stay in for

1537
01:19:17.440 --> 01:19:18.900
the rest of Linux plus.

1538
01:19:18.900 --> 01:19:22.840
And you'll find that, aside from those
update utilities, pretty much everything

1539
01:19:22.840 --> 01:19:25.820
else is done identically between
the various distributions.

1540
01:19:25.820 --> 01:19:29.840
And so, it really doesn't matter if you
want to continue on with Debian, you can.

1541
01:19:29.840 --> 01:19:31.770
If you want to switch over to CentOS,
you can.

1542
01:19:31.770 --> 01:19:32.500
Just pick one.

1543
01:19:32.500 --> 01:19:34.200
Pick one that makes you happy.

1544
01:19:34.200 --> 01:19:35.440
And stick with it.

1545
01:19:35.440 --> 01:19:37.940
And really focus in on
the important commands,

1546
01:19:37.940 --> 01:19:39.930
which are what we're gonna
see in the next episode.

1547
01:19:39.930 --> 01:19:41.460
>> All right.
>> All right.

1548
01:19:41.460 --> 01:19:45.680
Well, let me just remind everybody that if
you have any questions on what we covered

1549
01:19:45.680 --> 01:19:48.800
live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

1550
01:19:48.800 --> 01:19:50.520
You'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

1551
01:19:50.520 --> 01:19:54.300
You can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer.

1552
01:19:54.300 --> 01:19:57.790
If you are watching this recorded,
you can use our Q and A forums.

1553
01:19:57.790 --> 01:20:00.460
Just use that Q and
A link up at the top of the page.

1554
01:20:00.460 --> 01:20:03.580
We monitor that and answer, so we want to
make sure you guys get the information you

1555
01:20:03.580 --> 01:20:04.772
need so you can be successful.

1556
01:20:04.772 --> 01:20:06.180
All right.

1557
01:20:06.180 --> 01:20:07.820
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1558
01:20:07.820 --> 01:20:09.840
Signing out for ITPro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

1559
01:20:09.840 --> 01:20:10.820
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1560

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss the use of file editors. They list several of the different file editors and talk about their availability among different distros. The demonstrate the use of vi, the file editor that is found in just about every distro available. They show the power of vi to create a file, modify and save a file. They discuss the use of vi directly, on a consoled connection and a remote connection as well. They go through the basic commands that every Linux Admin needs to know when using a file editor.

01:02:09.950 --> 01:02:12.795

01:02:31.680 --> 01:02:36.530
few other things that we might want,

1133
01:02:36.530 --> 01:02:41.551
If we're editing a really big file,
if this file has thousands of lines in it,

01:02:41.551 --> 01:02:44.303

01:02:46.451 --> 01:02:47.970

01:02:47.970 --> 01:02:50.460

1138
01:02:50.460 --> 01:02:52.250
you're trying to find
something in particular.

1139
01:02:53.520 --> 01:02:58.093
When you're in command mode, not in insert
mode, but when you're in command mode,

1140
01:02:58.093 --> 01:02:59.688

1141
01:02:59.688 --> 01:03:06.060

to say, I wanna search for something.

1142
01:03:06.060 --> 01:03:08.850

then whatever it is you're searching for.

1143
01:03:08.850 --> 01:03:11.770
So I want to search for
the word, visiting.

1144
01:03:11.770 --> 01:03:14.200
So I'm gonna type /visiting.

1145
01:03:14.200 --> 01:03:17.500
And it's going to do
a forward scan searching for

1146
01:03:17.500 --> 01:03:19.550
the word visiting, all right?

1147
01:03:19.550 --> 01:03:23.040
It's case sensitive, and
it's going to scan to try and find it.

1148
01:03:23.040 --> 01:03:24.760
And hopefully it finds it, there it is.

1149
01:03:24.760 --> 01:03:28.450
So it just jumped forward in
the file to find that instance.

1150
01:03:28.450 --> 01:03:33.523
If that's not the one that I wanted,
you can just do /visiting again,

1151
01:03:33.523 --> 01:03:35.670
and it'll repeat it and do the search.

1152
01:03:35.670 --> 01:03:38.270
And I can see mine hit the bottom,
and there we go.

1153
01:03:38.270 --> 01:03:41.800
And actually on a lot of systems, you
can just type slash and press enter, and

1154
01:03:41.800 --> 01:03:44.318
it'll repeat the same search
that it did a moment ago.

1155
01:03:44.318 --> 01:03:46.780
So, that's a little bit of a short cut.

1156
01:03:46.780 --> 01:03:49.832
It finds the first one and
you just do slash Enter, slash Enter,

1157
01:03:49.832 --> 01:03:51.821
and it keeps jumping to find the next one.

1158
01:03:51.821 --> 01:03:56.194
So for example,
if I did a search for body.

1159
01:03:56.194 --> 01:04:00.370
Okay, it finds the first one and
then I can do just slash Enter.

1160
01:04:00.370 --> 01:04:01.564
And it finds the second one.

1161
01:04:01.564 --> 01:04:05.190
So it just jumped down, and
it took me to the second instance.

1162
01:04:06.270 --> 01:04:09.630
So that slash, quick way to search and
find something.

1163
01:04:09.630 --> 01:04:12.770
And you find it and
then you hit your Insert key, and

1164
01:04:12.770 --> 01:04:15.480

the change to whatever that tag is.

1165
01:04:16.590 --> 01:04:18.371
So that's another shortcut
that's pretty handy.

1166
01:04:18.371 --> 01:04:20.690
Just a forward slash
initiates that search.

1167
01:04:23.080 --> 01:04:26.650

1168
01:04:26.650 --> 01:04:32.530

1169
01:04:32.530 --> 01:04:38.950

1170
01:04:38.950 --> 01:04:44.289

1171
01:04:44.289 --> 01:04:46.360

1172
01:04:47.830 --> 01:04:49.990
There's some variations of that.

1173
01:04:49.990 --> 01:04:51.885
Back in command mode, if I do a capital I.

1174
01:04:51.885 --> 01:04:57.110
So I did a lower case i, lower case i says
insert wherever my cursor is right now.

1175
01:04:57.110 --> 01:05:03.360
If you do a capital I, that means
insert at the beginning of the line.

1176
01:05:03.360 --> 01:05:05.210
And so you'll see,
I did a capital I that time.

1177
01:05:05.210 --> 01:05:09.162

1178
01:05:09.162 --> 01:05:12.480
So insert from the beginning

1179
01:05:12.480 --> 01:05:16.670
I don't normally do that, but

1180
01:05:18.670 --> 01:05:21.400
We also might wanna do this

1181
01:05:21.400 --> 01:05:26.920
When I do a lower case i, it inserts

1182
01:05:26.920 --> 01:05:31.160
If you do a lower case a,
it's actually append and

1183
01:05:31.160 --> 01:05:34.700

1184
01:05:34.700 --> 01:05:39.800
Now, I don't use that one very often,

1185
01:05:39.800 --> 01:05:43.570
Capital A's append at the end
of the current line, and so

1186
01:05:43.570 --> 01:05:47.120
now it jumps to the end of the line.

1187
01:05:47.120 --> 01:05:48.690
So if you wanna add something
to the end of that line,

1188
01:05:48.690 --> 01:05:49.998
a capital A will jump you there.

1189
01:05:49.998 --> 01:05:52.920
So lower case i,

1190
01:05:52.920 --> 01:05:58.100
insert before my cursor, lower case a,
insert after my current cursor.

1191
01:05:58.100 --> 01:06:01.550
Capital I, insert at the beginning
of the line, capital A,

1192
01:06:01.550 --> 01:06:02.630
insert at the end of the line.

1193
01:06:02.630 --> 01:06:06.287

01:06:10.620 --> 01:06:12.662

01:06:53.410 --> 01:06:56.960

00:50:03.318 --> 00:50:08.740

00:50:08.740 --> 00:50:13.870
Which is a lot of processes that run

00:50:30.928 --> 00:50:33.130

00:50:33.130 --> 00:50:37.850
When you're in a command line interface,

00:50:37.850 --> 00:50:41.060
So let's run through some

00:50:41.060 --> 00:50:45.270
When we run a program, almost everything

00:50:45.270 --> 00:50:48.140

00:50:48.140 --> 00:50:52.800

00:50:52.800 --> 00:50:54.953

00:50:54.953 --> 00:50:56.330
Right?

958
00:50:56.330 --> 00:50:58.560
But there are times when we
want to run something and

959
00:50:58.560 --> 00:51:00.590
have it run in the background.

960
00:51:00.590 --> 00:51:04.840
Where you want it to keep running,

961
00:51:04.840 --> 00:51:11.160
An example might be, lets say,

962
00:51:11.160 --> 00:51:16.090
I want to bring up a sequel data,
MySQL database, and store some data in it,

00:51:16.090 --> 00:51:17.300
do some testing.

964
00:51:17.300 --> 00:51:20.180
But I don't want to install it on
the server and have it run as a service.

965
00:51:20.180 --> 00:51:21.020
I don't want it always running.

966
00:51:21.020 --> 00:51:24.140
I just want it running
while I test with it, okay.

967
00:51:24.140 --> 00:51:27.436
So, I might install MySQL in here,
which I've already done.

968
00:51:27.436 --> 00:51:32.105
And then I might want to run it and
then work with it, okay?

969
00:51:32.105 --> 00:51:38.750
Well, if I run it,
we can do mysqld, the daemon for

970
00:51:38.750 --> 00:51:42.205
MySQL, which I don't think I've

971
00:51:42.205 --> 00:51:46.115
Is that services, things that run in
the background when the system boots up,

972
00:51:46.115 --> 00:51:49.710
they're called daemons, and

973
00:51:49.710 --> 00:51:52.741
I used to say daymons for

974
00:51:52.741 --> 00:51:57.115
then I watched some videos and

975
00:51:57.115 --> 00:52:00.028
So anyhow, the daemons, and
they run in the background and

976
00:52:00.028 --> 00:52:03.730
they just sit there, and they wait for
you to interact with them.

977
00:52:03.730 --> 00:52:07.680
So MySQL, the database server,
it's got a MySQL daemon,

978
00:52:07.680 --> 00:52:10.449
it's designed to run in the background.

979
00:52:10.449 --> 00:52:13.008
But if I just run this command,
I'm gonna bring it up in safe mode,

980
00:52:13.008 --> 00:52:14.820
which means just run it for me.

981
00:52:14.820 --> 00:52:19.080
When I run that, it fires up,
I don't have permission.

982
00:52:19.080 --> 00:52:21.280
Let me switch over to a root user.

983
00:52:21.280 --> 00:52:24.820

984
00:52:24.820 --> 00:52:28.990
When I run that, it runs and
now I'm running MySQL.

985
00:52:28.990 --> 00:52:32.678
It says it's starting up a session,
and now it's running.

986
00:52:32.678 --> 00:52:34.900
But notice it didn't put
me back to my prompt.

987
00:52:35.940 --> 00:52:40.920
I'm running MySQL and
I'm now trapped inside of it.

988
00:52:40.920 --> 00:52:41.800
It's a server.

989
00:52:41.800 --> 00:52:43.010
It's a service running in the background.

990
00:52:43.010 --> 00:52:47.770
It's waiting for me to send SQL commands
to it through the standard SQL ports.

991
00:52:47.770 --> 00:52:51.790
It's not expecting keyboard input,
and so it's just gonna sit here, and

992
00:52:51.790 --> 00:52:52.530
now I'm stuck.

993
00:52:52.530 --> 00:52:53.820
>> Yeah.
>> I'm dead in the water.

994
00:52:54.830 --> 00:52:57.300
So, what can I do about that?

995
00:52:57.300 --> 00:52:59.880
Well, there's actually a couple of neat
things that we can do when it comes to

996
00:52:59.880 --> 00:53:01.130
multitasking.

997
00:53:01.130 --> 00:53:03.944
If you are physically in
front of the machine,

998
00:53:03.944 --> 00:53:06.481
there's a neat little trick you can use.

999
00:53:06.481 --> 00:53:08.975
What we're looking at,
this console that we're looking at,

1000
00:53:08.975 --> 00:53:10.159
this is what's called a TTY.

1001
00:53:10.159 --> 00:53:13.665
All right, which that stands for
a teletype interface, for the,

1002
00:53:13.665 --> 00:53:16.928
well I don't wanna call it old system,
we still use it today.

1003
00:53:16.928 --> 00:53:21.559
For people like, if you're deaf and
you want to make a phone call, well,

1004
00:53:21.559 --> 00:53:25.611
you can't really make a phone call,
if you're unable to hear.

1005
00:53:25.611 --> 00:53:28.963
And so they have the teletype system,
where they're able to type, and it sends

1006
00:53:28.963 --> 00:53:32.620
that over the phone line to the other
side, where it's displayed on a screen.

1007
00:53:32.620 --> 00:53:36.583
That same teletype technology is what
power's our console on a Linux or

1008
00:53:36.583 --> 00:53:38.070
Unix-based machine.

1009
00:53:38.070 --> 00:53:40.200
So they call them TTYs.

1010
00:53:40.200 --> 00:53:42.270
And when you install Linux,
and you boot up, and

1011
00:53:42.270 --> 00:53:45.710
you log in to the first time,
you're on TTY number one.

1012
00:53:45.710 --> 00:53:50.220
Well, most distributions out
there create more than one TTY.

1013
00:53:50.220 --> 00:53:52.530
I'm on CentOS it does 6 by default.

1014
00:53:52.530 --> 00:53:53.600
All right, and so

1015
00:53:53.600 --> 00:53:59.670
what I can do is I can say well this
TTY is stuck running my SQL now right.

1016
00:53:59.670 --> 00:54:02.700
But I've got five more TTYs I can jump to.

1017
00:54:02.700 --> 00:54:09.700
And all you do is on your keyboard
you use ALT+ F1 through ALT + F6.

1018
00:54:09.700 --> 00:54:14.349
When you hit those, so
I'm on TTY1 which would be ALT + F1.

1019
00:54:14.349 --> 00:54:21.860
And if I do ALT + F2, I jump to an all
new TTY and I can get logged in here.

1020
00:54:21.860 --> 00:54:23.290
And I'm gonna break the rules and
log in as root.

1021
00:54:23.290 --> 00:54:26.769
And I'll type my password wrong.

1022
00:54:29.149 --> 00:54:31.880
So I can log in over here and

1023
00:54:31.880 --> 00:54:36.600
And see how when I run PS, I'm only seeing
things from my TTY and my user, right.

1024
00:54:36.600 --> 00:54:38.890
So I'm just seeing what
root is running here.

1025
00:54:38.890 --> 00:54:42.390
But if I do ps aux, and that will be so

1026
00:54:42.390 --> 00:54:46.550
much nicer later when we learn about grep,

1027
00:54:46.550 --> 00:54:50.390
But I can see right here on

1028
00:54:50.390 --> 00:54:55.150
And it's running, you know, for well for
itself really, but that's what's running

1029
00:54:55.150 --> 00:54:59.220
in my other TTY, so I can see it right

1030
00:55:00.340 --> 00:55:04.814
And so now I could do something here,
and then I could hit ALT+F3 and

00:55:04.814 --> 00:55:06.572
there's another one.

1032
00:55:06.572 --> 00:55:11.180
And ALT+F4, 5, 6,
each one of those is a different TTY.

1033
00:55:11.180 --> 00:55:13.975
I can login as different users.

1034
00:55:13.975 --> 00:55:15.210
So here I am on TTY6.

1035
00:55:15.210 --> 00:55:19.003
Now, be careful with that
message that pops up,

1036
00:55:19.003 --> 00:55:23.175

00:55:23.175 --> 00:55:25.668
Okay?

00:55:25.668 --> 00:55:28.132
that doesn't mean I'm on TTY1 now.

1039
00:55:28.132 --> 00:55:33.298
I'm actually on TTY6, if I do ps,
I'll see it right there.

1040
00:55:33.298 --> 00:55:38.058
From there I can jump back, ALT+F4,
ALT+F2, here's that other root instance,

1041
00:55:38.058 --> 00:55:40.610
ALT+F1, there's where MySQL is running.

1042
00:55:40.610 --> 00:55:45.818
This is basic multi tasking,
if you're sitting at your machine.

1043
00:55:45.818 --> 00:55:49.421
If you're sitting at the machine, you can
do this ALT+F1, ALT+F6 or whatever, and

1044
00:55:49.421 --> 00:55:50.680
jump between these sessions.

1045
00:55:50.680 --> 00:55:55.138
And you can run six interactive programs,
all at the same time, right.

1046
00:55:55.138 --> 00:55:58.180
So quick and easy,
if you're at the machine.

1047
00:55:58.180 --> 00:55:59.310
But what if we're not at the machine?

00:55:59.310 --> 00:56:00.053
>> Hm.

1049
00:56:00.053 --> 00:56:01.780

00:56:01.780 --> 00:56:05.440
Well when you SSH in to a server,

00:56:09.040 --> 00:56:11.360

1053
00:56:11.360 --> 00:56:12.100

1054
00:56:12.100 --> 00:56:14.160
You could have six windows,

1055
00:56:14.160 --> 00:56:16.120

00:56:50.510 --> 00:56:55.255
When you're dealing multiple TTYs like we

00:56:55.255 --> 00:56:57.380

00:56:57.380 --> 00:57:05.625
So before the break I had logged in like

00:57:05.625 --> 00:57:10.685

00:57:10.685 --> 00:57:14.910

00:57:14.910 --> 00:57:19.570

00:57:46.280 --> 00:57:48.410

00:57:48.410 --> 00:57:52.460
And so you might not remember if you

1084
00:57:52.460 --> 00:57:54.460

00:57:54.460 --> 00:57:58.460

1086
00:57:58.460 --> 00:58:03.009

1087
00:58:03.009 --> 00:58:06.690
So [LAUGH] alright, so

1088
00:58:06.690 --> 00:58:13.760
Now back over here,

00:58:13.760 --> 00:58:17.830

00:58:17.830 --> 00:58:23.230

00:58:23.230 --> 00:58:27.370

00:58:30.040 --> 00:58:32.540

00:58:32.540 --> 00:58:34.843

00:58:34.843 --> 00:58:39.020

00:58:39.020 --> 00:58:41.500

00:58:41.500 --> 00:58:43.510

00:58:43.510 --> 00:58:47.010

00:58:47.010 --> 00:58:48.640

00:58:48.640 --> 00:58:53.460

00:58:56.876 --> 00:59:03.630

00:59:03.630 --> 00:59:04.965

00:59:04.965 --> 00:59:07.025

00:59:07.025 --> 00:59:10.580

00:59:10.580 --> 00:59:13.000

00:59:13.000 --> 00:59:15.370
That doesn't mean that MySQLl

1108
00:59:15.370 --> 00:59:19.650
It just stopped having control

00:59:19.650 --> 00:59:21.730

00:59:21.730 --> 00:59:23.580

00:59:23.580 --> 00:59:25.780
Well there's a few ways I can verify that,

00:59:25.780 --> 00:59:27.340
There's the ps command.

00:59:27.340 --> 00:59:30.620

00:59:30.620 --> 00:59:35.070

00:59:35.070 --> 00:59:37.560

00:59:37.560 --> 00:59:40.900
When you run jobs it shows you

00:59:40.900 --> 00:59:45.050

1118
00:59:45.050 --> 00:59:47.875

if you wanna get back to it.

1119
00:59:47.875 --> 00:59:49.360
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right.

1120
00:59:49.360 --> 00:59:52.640
How do I reconnect to that program if I

1121
00:59:52.640 --> 00:59:56.830
Well I can run jobs and

00:59:56.830 --> 01:00:00.095

1123

So MySQLd is running as job number one,

1124
01:00:07.385 --> 01:00:11.650

01:00:25.130 --> 01:00:26.660

01:00:26.660 --> 01:00:28.210
If you've never seen it,
let me just run it.

1130
01:00:28.210 --> 01:00:29.390
Here it we go.

1131
01:00:29.390 --> 01:00:31.690
And it gives you a little
graphical representation, and

1132
01:00:31.690 --> 01:00:34.150
you can go through here and

1133
01:00:34.150 --> 01:00:38.150

01:00:38.150 --> 01:00:41.580
And so if I run it, here it is,

01:06:28.360 --> 01:06:31.420
So they each get even
access to the system.

1248
01:06:31.420 --> 01:06:36.620

01:06:41.530 --> 01:06:46.260

01:06:46.260 --> 01:06:50.512

1253
01:06:50.512 --> 01:06:57.580

01:06:57.580 --> 01:07:02.167

01:09:25.465 --> 01:09:28.505

01:09:28.505 --> 01:09:30.965

01:09:30.965 --> 01:09:34.765

01:09:34.765 --> 01:09:37.693

01:09:37.693 --> 01:09:39.085

01:09:39.085 --> 01:09:40.995
You are number one, right?

1309
01:09:40.995 --> 01:09:41.624
Negative 20.

1310
01:09:42.770 --> 01:09:47.170
Positive 19,

01:09:47.170 --> 01:09:50.080

1312
01:09:50.080 --> 01:09:52.270

01:09:52.270 --> 01:09:55.830

01:09:55.830 --> 01:09:58.040

01:10:02.190 --> 01:10:06.740

01:10:10.310 --> 01:10:14.740
So, we can start to manipulate which

01:10:15.700 --> 01:10:18.240

01:10:18.240 --> 01:10:21.180
Whatever's in the foreground is what

01:10:21.180 --> 01:10:25.479
But on a server, it's often that you have

1323

01:10:28.815 --> 01:10:32.490

01:10:32.490 --> 01:10:34.710

01:10:34.710 --> 01:10:37.660

01:49:32.865 --> 01:49:34.760
That way I still have the original
in case I mess things up.

2035
01:49:37.244 --> 01:49:40.471
When you run that,
sed is gonna scan your file and

2036
01:49:40.471 --> 01:49:44.742
every instance of the word love
is gonna change to the word hate.

2037
01:49:44.742 --> 01:49:49.310
And now it's gonna output test1.txt and
we should see our change.

2038
01:49:49.310 --> 01:49:55.040
If I do more test1.txt, there it is.

2039
01:49:55.040 --> 01:49:56.816
Now, I hate Blackberry phones!!!

2040
01:49:56.816 --> 01:50:00.830
So really cool, because sed can just
get in there and make that change.

2041
01:50:00.830 --> 01:50:05.570
If you want a script or automated
change across hundreds of servers,

2042
01:50:05.570 --> 01:50:10.569
you can use sed to edit those files,
make your changes, very powerful.

2043
01:50:11.648 --> 01:50:12.773
>> Very nice.

2044
01:50:12.773 --> 01:50:16.593
>> I'm down to just six more commands-
>> [LAUGH]

2045
01:50:16.593 --> 01:50:17.898
>> And these are really,

2046
01:50:17.898 --> 01:50:19.414
really simple commands.

2047
01:50:19.414 --> 01:50:23.945
When we get screen output, if we
wanna feed that into another command,

2048
01:50:23.945 --> 01:50:27.053
sometimes the screen output
is not right for us.

2049
01:50:27.053 --> 01:50:30.436
It just contains too much information or
not enough information, and

2050
01:50:30.436 --> 01:50:32.120
we need to manipulate it.

2051
01:50:32.120 --> 01:50:35.930
So there's a series of commands that
we can use to kinda tailor what we get.

2052
01:50:37.570 --> 01:50:39.610
Tr is one of them.

2053
01:50:39.610 --> 01:50:42.808
Tr, I always call it the trim command.

2054
01:50:42.808 --> 01:50:46.514
It actually stands for translate,
I don't know why that is,

2055
01:50:46.514 --> 01:50:50.808
but it's a trim command that we can
use to modify how text is displayed.

2056
01:50:50.808 --> 01:50:53.304
It's got a few different forms,

2057
01:50:53.304 --> 01:50:57.414
the one I mostly use is
the squeeze form which is tr-s.

2058
01:50:57.414 --> 01:51:01.070
You can do tr-d to delete
characters out of something.

2059
01:51:02.110 --> 01:51:06.880
For example,
let's say that I go to my ls -la output.

2060
01:51:08.120 --> 01:51:11.583
It outputs all this information,
and it's close to what I want.

2061
01:51:11.583 --> 01:51:13.650
I wanna get a list of files
in my home directory.

2062
01:51:14.660 --> 01:51:19.170
If I just do ls, I get them, but
they're not in the right format for me.

2063
01:51:19.170 --> 01:51:22.790
So I want them all vertically,
just a list of the files.

2064
01:51:22.790 --> 01:51:26.163
And if I do ls -la I get that, but
there's a lot of other data in here.

2065
01:51:26.163 --> 01:51:29.510
So maybe I just wanna get
the data that's over here,

2066
01:51:29.510 --> 01:51:33.730
the filenames as they're
floating over here and that's it.

2067
01:51:33.730 --> 01:51:36.148
Well, I need to cut out all
this other information and

2068
01:51:36.148 --> 01:51:37.668
there is actually a cut command.

2069
01:51:37.668 --> 01:51:41.112
We'll see where we could cut that out,
cut those characters out and

2070
01:51:41.112 --> 01:51:42.450
get to just the filename.

2071
01:51:42.450 --> 01:51:46.200
But there's also the availability
to base it on the columns.

2072
01:51:46.200 --> 01:51:49.207
So I've got one column of data here,
another here, another here, another here.

2073
01:51:49.207 --> 01:51:52.335
But in order to do that we have
to have some kind of delimiter.

2074
01:51:52.335 --> 01:51:56.493
And you'll see in this command
sometimes that delimiter is one space.

2075
01:51:56.493 --> 01:51:59.685
Sometimes it's two spaces,
always one space right here.

2076
01:51:59.685 --> 01:52:04.710
But here it might be five spaces, six
spaces so it's not a standard delimiter.

2077
01:52:04.710 --> 01:52:08.900
We can use tr with the squeeze
modifier to change these, so

2078
01:52:08.900 --> 01:52:11.110
they all have the same delimiter.

2079
01:52:11.110 --> 01:52:16.330
So I could say ls- la, and feed that into

2080
01:52:16.330 --> 01:52:23.310
the squeeze modifier of tr and
tell it to look for something like spaces.

2081
01:52:23.310 --> 01:52:24.370
Actually is it double quotes?

2082
01:52:24.370 --> 01:52:26.150
I think it is single quotes.

2083
01:52:26.150 --> 01:52:28.090
So look for spaces and

2084
01:52:28.090 --> 01:52:31.760
anytime there's more than one space in
a row, squeeze it to a single space.

2085
01:52:33.155 --> 01:52:36.840
And when I run that,
I'll see that my output is the same.

2086
01:52:36.840 --> 01:52:40.072
It's just now there's never
more than one space in a row.

2087
01:52:40.072 --> 01:52:44.590
So that translate or tr command is
letting me collapse those characters.

2088
01:52:46.300 --> 01:52:49.490
Now, I can take this and
feed it into something like cut.

2089
01:52:49.490 --> 01:52:55.460
The cut command, let's us cut out
a certain piece of text that we want.

2090
01:52:55.460 --> 01:52:58.790
And you can do it based on
where it's located numerically,

2091
01:52:58.790 --> 01:53:02.160
the 50th character to the 55th
character if you want.

2092
01:53:02.160 --> 01:53:06.970
But when you got a column data like this,
it's better to grab a particular column.

2093
01:53:06.970 --> 01:53:08.860
So we can feed in a few different things.

2094
01:53:10.040 --> 01:53:13.552
If we just wanted to do by character,
I could count these characters here,

2095
01:53:13.552 --> 01:53:14.504
this boring.

2096
01:53:14.504 --> 01:53:17.118
One, two, three, four, five, six, and

2097
01:53:17.118 --> 01:53:21.432
count all the way over to where our
filename started and I could just say,

2098
01:53:21.432 --> 01:53:24.213
cut out and
give me this character to that one.

2099
01:53:24.213 --> 01:53:31.330
You would say basically cut -c and
then you would say, 2-4.

2100
01:53:31.330 --> 01:53:34.430
That would say give me
characters 2 through 4.

2101
01:53:34.430 --> 01:53:38.145
So if we look at ls -la, and

2102
01:53:38.145 --> 01:53:43.486
we pipe that into cut, c, -c2-4.

2103
01:53:43.486 --> 01:53:47.172
Now I just get characters 2 through 4,
cut out character 1 and

2104
01:53:47.172 --> 01:53:51.810
then it gave me 2 through 4, and
then cut out 5 through the rest of it.

2105
01:53:51.810 --> 01:53:55.710
So you can use it that way, if you
have columns though with a delimiter,

2106
01:53:55.710 --> 01:53:59.250
you can feed off of that, you can
get really powerful with this stuff.

2107
01:53:59.250 --> 01:54:03.645
I'm going to take ls -la,
I'm gonna pipe that into tr -s,

2108
01:54:03.645 --> 01:54:06.328
and squeeze those spaces together.

2109
01:54:06.328 --> 01:54:11.510
So I can use the space as my
delimeter between columns.

2110
01:54:11.510 --> 01:54:17.258
And then I'm gonna send
that into cut -d' ',

2111
01:54:17.258 --> 01:54:21.430
I'm saying my delimiter is a space.

2112
01:54:21.430 --> 01:54:24.360
So everywhere you see a space,
that's the end of one column and

2113
01:54:24.360 --> 01:54:25.540
the start of another column.

2114
01:54:26.940 --> 01:54:32.573
And then I can tell it, whoops, -f 3,9.

2115
01:54:32.573 --> 01:54:36.900
I want fields 3 and 9.

2116
01:54:36.900 --> 01:54:42.310
So look up here at my ls -la output and

2117
01:54:42.310 --> 01:54:45.660
we've got column one,
column two, column three.

2118
01:54:45.660 --> 01:54:47.170
I want the username.

2119
01:54:47.170 --> 01:54:50.774
Column four, column five, column six,
column seven, column eight, column nine.

2120
01:54:50.774 --> 01:54:51.590
I want the filename.

2121
01:54:52.660 --> 01:54:54.615
So give me the username and the filename.

2122
01:54:55.860 --> 01:54:59.120
And when I run that,
I get exactly what I wanted.

2123
01:54:59.120 --> 01:55:00.995
Just the username and the filename.

2124
01:55:00.995 --> 01:55:03.773
If I don't want the username,
I just cut out column number three and

2125
01:55:03.773 --> 01:55:05.836
go down to column number nine,
and I can run that.

2126
01:55:05.836 --> 01:55:07.670
And now I just get-
>> Nice.

2127
01:55:07.670 --> 01:55:09.737
>> The filenames in a nice vertical-
>> [LAUGH]

2128
01:55:09.737 --> 01:55:10.898
>> Alignment.

2129
01:55:10.898 --> 01:55:11.653
That's a lot of work, isn't it?

2130
01:55:11.653 --> 01:55:12.198
>> It is.

2131
01:55:12.198 --> 01:55:18.022
>> So ls gave it to me in a horizontal
alignment and it's screen wrapped.

2132
01:55:18.022 --> 01:55:22.297
Ls -la gave it to me in a vertical
alignment, but it was kinda hard for

2133
01:55:22.297 --> 01:55:26.309
me to get to where I could pair
that down to exactly what I wanted.

2134
01:55:26.309 --> 01:55:29.534
I had to feed it into
the translate command to shrink or

2135
01:55:29.534 --> 01:55:32.020
squeeze those spaces together.

2136
01:55:32.020 --> 01:55:34.800
And then I had to use cut with a delimiter

2137
01:55:34.800 --> 01:55:38.488
to grab particular fields out of
it to just get the filename field.

2138
01:55:38.488 --> 01:55:39.399
So that's-
>> [LAUGH]

2139
01:55:39.399 --> 01:55:41.083
>> An example of how complex we can get

2140
01:55:41.083 --> 01:55:42.030
with this.

2141
01:55:42.030 --> 01:55:44.530
But if you need data in a certain way,
you can certainly get it.

2142
01:55:46.790 --> 01:55:51.953
The only other ones just three last
little ones, expand and unexpand.

2143
01:55:51.953 --> 01:55:53.961
I really don't use these.

2144
01:55:53.961 --> 01:55:58.526
If you have got a file that
contains tabs you can use

2145
01:55:58.526 --> 01:56:03.098
the expand command to
expand the tab into spaces.

2146
01:56:03.098 --> 01:56:07.924
I guess I could whip up an example but
really,

2147
01:56:07.924 --> 01:56:13.258
if I say expand and
then I say something like well,

2148
01:56:13.258 --> 01:56:17.579
it's not gonna echo this to the screen.

2149
01:56:17.579 --> 01:56:18.720
What would be a good way to do this?

2150
01:56:18.720 --> 01:56:24.728
If I say echo "This, this is not gonna
let me tab from the command line.

2151
01:56:24.728 --> 01:56:25.691
Well-
>> Yeah.

2152
01:56:25.691 --> 01:56:29.331
>> Anyhow, if we have a file with tabs
in it, if you do expand on that file,

2153
01:56:29.331 --> 01:56:31.969
it will take every tab and
just turn it into spaces.

2154
01:56:31.969 --> 01:56:33.605
Five spaces instead of one tab.

2155
01:56:33.605 --> 01:56:34.511
>> Tabs.

2156
01:56:34.511 --> 01:56:38.476
>> Unexpand does the same thing, anytime
it sees a bunch of spaces in a row,

2157
01:56:38.476 --> 01:56:40.040
it converts them into a tab.

2158
01:56:41.720 --> 01:56:46.295
So pretty straight forward there if you
look at the unexpand, it will tell you.

2159
01:56:46.295 --> 01:56:50.659
You can modify exactly how many
tabs does space equals and so on.

2160
01:56:50.659 --> 01:56:52.332
I said the default was five.

2161
01:56:52.332 --> 01:56:55.374
It looks like the default is eight.

2162
01:56:55.374 --> 01:56:56.256
No, I'm glad I checked that.

2163
01:56:56.256 --> 01:56:57.452
>> Yeah.
>> So yeah, the default is eight.

2164
01:56:57.452 --> 01:57:00.440
But you can use -t to
manipulate that value, so

2165
01:57:00.440 --> 01:57:02.919
expand and unexpand can change those.

2166
01:57:02.919 --> 01:57:10.985
FMT, that's another one
I gotta run this way.

2167
01:57:10.985 --> 01:57:15.510
You see FMT, it's designed to
reformat the flow of a document.

2168
01:57:15.510 --> 01:57:19.620
So you may have a width,
the height like margins on it.

2169
01:57:19.620 --> 01:57:22.929
And it can go in and
adjust that changing pagination.

2170
01:57:22.929 --> 01:57:25.160
Talks about crown margin and so on.

2171
01:57:25.160 --> 01:57:28.980
You can split it up very similar to PR,
getting it ready for print.

2172
01:57:28.980 --> 01:57:30.960
Except PR wants to add little headers and
stuff.

2173
01:57:30.960 --> 01:57:32.656
FMT doesn't,
well unless you tell it to do it.

2174
01:57:32.656 --> 01:57:37.692
So FMT is another one that we
can use to manipulate our data,

2175
01:57:37.692 --> 01:57:39.924
and the last one is split.

2176
01:57:39.924 --> 01:57:45.000
Split we can use to divide up
a file into multiple files.

2177
01:57:45.000 --> 01:57:51.138
Now this didn't used to be very useful but
actually, it can be useful today.

2178
01:57:51.138 --> 01:57:55.341
If you wanna move data between
a Linux box and a Windows box.

2179
01:57:55.341 --> 01:58:00.339
Well Linux likes to format
things [LAUGH] ext4-

2180
01:58:00.339 --> 01:58:01.221
>> Ext.

2181
01:58:01.221 --> 01:58:02.559
[LAUGH]
>> There we go, and

2182
01:58:02.559 --> 01:58:06.430
Windows likes to format things NTFS, and
they support large files or whatever.

2183
01:58:06.430 --> 01:58:08.441
But if you wanna move between them,

2184
01:58:08.441 --> 01:58:11.401
the only real common stable
file system is FAT32.

2185
01:58:11.401 --> 01:58:16.259
I guess we have exFAT now, but the FAT32
for the longest time was the best one, and

2186
01:58:16.259 --> 01:58:19.570
it wouldn't take files
over 2 gigs in size.

2187
01:58:19.570 --> 01:58:22.970
So if you wanted to move a 5 gig file
between the systems you really couldn't,

2188
01:58:22.970 --> 01:58:24.410
not that way at least.

2189
01:58:24.410 --> 01:58:30.150
So we could use the split command
to break a file up into pieces.

2190
01:58:30.150 --> 01:58:33.860
And then on the other side we could
join the files back together again and

2191
01:58:33.860 --> 01:58:35.000
have it combined.

2192
01:58:35.000 --> 01:58:38.960
I used to use this back in the floppy disk
days cuz you might need to break something

2193
01:58:38.960 --> 01:58:42.710
up across a bunch of 1.44 megabyte
floppy disks and go that way.

2194
01:58:42.710 --> 01:58:47.591
So if I wanna break up a file,
like I'll take that VMware Tools.

2195
01:58:47.591 --> 01:58:51.950
It's 61 megs in size,
maybe I wanna break it up in 10 meg files.

2196
01:58:51.950 --> 01:58:57.760
So I can just come in here, and
I can run split -b to tell how many bytes.

2197
01:58:57.760 --> 01:59:01.889
I wanna break this up
into a 10 megabyte file.

2198
01:59:01.889 --> 01:59:05.248
And then I need to tell it the file
that I'm gonna be breaking up,

2199
01:59:05.248 --> 01:59:06.941
which is gonna be VMwareTools.

2200
01:59:06.941 --> 01:59:08.880
And then I need to tell it
what I'm wanna call it.

2201
01:59:08.880 --> 01:59:11.017
So I'll just call it vmtools,

2202
01:59:11.017 --> 01:59:15.962
actually you know what I'll just call
it tools sorta fit on the screen.

2203
01:59:15.962 --> 01:59:17.770
Now I'm gonna stop there with a dot.

2204
01:59:17.770 --> 01:59:20.280
And the reason is,
when it generates these new files,

2205
01:59:20.280 --> 01:59:24.970
it's gonna add an extension to the end
that tells us what the file order is.

2206
01:59:24.970 --> 01:59:30.458
When I run that, it's gonna break
that file up and now when I look,

2207
01:59:30.458 --> 01:59:34.968
see how I've got tools.aa,
ab, ac, ad, and so on.

2208
01:59:34.968 --> 01:59:39.272
And when it reaches az,
then it goes to ba, bb, bc, and so on.

2209
01:59:39.272 --> 01:59:42.430
So it just broke it up into 10 meg files.

2210
01:59:44.390 --> 01:59:47.810
Now we can copy those to our media,
send them to the other side, and

2211
01:59:47.810 --> 01:59:50.500
at the other side we can just
combine them back again.

2212
01:59:50.500 --> 01:59:53.680
You combine them using the cat command and

2213
01:59:53.680 --> 01:59:56.700

2214
01:59:56.700 --> 01:59:59.722
We basically say, cat tools.??

01:59:59.722 --> 02:00:03.761
So anything called tools dot and

2216
02:00:03.761 --> 02:00:08.905
And then we pipe it's output into

2217
02:00:08.905 --> 02:00:12.395
So I'll do it in the tools.tgz.

2218
02:00:12.395 --> 02:00:14.905
And when we run that,
