2219
02:00:14.905 --> 02:00:18.533
And put them together so when I look,

2220
02:00:18.533 --> 02:00:24.049

02:00:24.049 --> 02:00:26.900
See, it's the exact same as

2222
02:00:26.900 --> 02:00:28.531
So we can use split to break it apart.

2223
02:00:28.531 --> 02:00:29.088

2224
02:00:29.088 --> 02:00:34.233

that are fairly hard to understand if

39

And so, we made the decision to

40

the commands and the file systems,

41

what's in the exam objectives, but

46
00:02:21.430 --> 00:02:23.920
it makes more logical sense.

47
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:26.680
All right, so, for system architecture,

48
00:02:26.680 --> 00:02:29.900
it starts to dive into some
pretty unusual concepts.

49
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:32.410
It's really built around
the idea of identifying

50
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:35.360
hardware [COUGH] that's
in use by the system.

51
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:40.020
And how Linux sees the hardware,
how it interacts with the hardware and

52
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:41.840
how it represents it to you.

53
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:45.300
Now we've already seen that a little
bit when we worked with hard drives.

54
00:02:45.300 --> 00:02:48.995
We saw things like /dev/sda1 and
so on, and

55
00:02:48.995 --> 00:02:52.804
those were file
representations of hardware.

56
00:02:52.804 --> 00:02:54.920
But you'll see there's a lot more to it.

57
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:58.579
And so that's what we're gonna be taking
a look at as we move through system

58
00:02:58.579 --> 00:02:59.400
architecture.

59
00:03:00.830 --> 00:03:04.190
All right, so let's talk a little bit
about that whole /dev folder, all right.

60
00:03:04.190 --> 00:03:09.890
It is a folder on the hard drive, we can
browse to it, just cd/dev and off you go.

61
00:03:09.890 --> 00:03:15.060
And when you're in there,
you see stuff, right, a lot of stuff.

62
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:16.370
In fact, let me pull it up here,

63
00:03:16.370 --> 00:03:20.990
so everybody knows I'm not lying,
that there is actually stuff in there.

64
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:24.390
So, when I pull up the list, you'll
see there's a bunch of junk in there.

65
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:27.230
And what these are are file
representations of our hardware.

66
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:30.690
Now, we were working with
the hard drive ones, right?

67
00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:38.380
So, sda for scsi disk a, the first one,
and scsi disk b, scsi disk c, and so on.

68
00:03:38.380 --> 00:03:44.560
And you have sda1, sda2, and so on for
the partitions inside of those disks.

69
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:49.200
You've also got ttys, those are for your
teletypes, your consoles on the system.

70
00:03:49.200 --> 00:03:50.940
You've got other things in here too.

71
00:03:50.940 --> 00:03:54.110
Basically, all of your hardware is
represented one way or another in here.

72
00:03:55.140 --> 00:03:59.060
Now, we talked a little bit about those,
about those files that are there.

73
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:04.620
But there's also some directories that
are in here that each have a purpose also.

74
00:04:04.620 --> 00:04:09.890
So you'll see like disc,
cpu, mapper, net and so on.

75
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:12.490
These are our places that
we can browse into and

76
00:04:12.490 --> 00:04:16.110
start to get additional
information about our hardware.

77
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:20.270
Some of these are links, like dvd, dvdrw,

78
00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:24.800
a lot of those will be links that just
link right back to CD-ROM or whatever.

79
00:04:24.800 --> 00:04:27.120
So you do see some variations, all right.

80
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:31.940
Now, how did these files get
here in the first place?

81
00:04:31.940 --> 00:04:36.120
Well, in your Linux distribution,
under the hood in the background,

82
00:04:36.120 --> 00:04:39.940
there's a process called udev, U-D-E-V.

83
00:04:39.940 --> 00:04:44.290
And udev is that back end side
that's identifying your hardware and

84
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:46.980
creating these representations right here.

85
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:48.220
So udev is responsible for

86
00:04:48.220 --> 00:04:53.220
that, now udev is one of those areas
that has really advanced over the years.

87
00:04:53.220 --> 00:04:57.980
When I first got started with Linux,
we had what were called static mappings,

88
00:04:57.980 --> 00:05:00.430
Linux didn't actually know
what hardware was there.

89
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:02.731
And so
it would create static mappings here for

90
00:05:02.731 --> 00:05:05.470
devices that you didn't even have,
all right?

91
00:05:05.470 --> 00:05:10.300
So you might only have one hard drive
in your system, but it used to be that

92
00:05:10.300 --> 00:05:14.660
you browsed into /dev, and you would see
hda, hdb, hdc, all the way to hdz, for

93
00:05:14.660 --> 00:05:17.910
up to 26 hard drives, and
you might only have one, right?

94
00:05:17.910 --> 00:05:21.190
It didn't know, so it just went ahead and
created all the mappings for it, and if

95
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:25.320
you accessed one of them that correlated
to a real hard drive, it worked.

96
00:05:25.320 --> 00:05:28.033
But if you accessed one that connected
to a hard drive that didn't exist,

97
00:05:28.033 --> 00:05:29.146
you'd get an error, right.

98
00:05:29.146 --> 00:05:31.960
And so it made it where
when you browsed into /dev,

99
00:05:31.960 --> 00:05:34.560
it was a massive amount of data in there.

100
00:05:34.560 --> 00:05:37.820
And a lot of the hardware wasn't
even really present, okay?

101
00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:42.590
Well now, the hardware is
dynamically detected by udev, and

102
00:05:42.590 --> 00:05:44.900
when it finds it,
it then creates the mapping.

103
00:05:44.900 --> 00:05:48.580
So when we look at this list here, that's
all the hardware that we really have.

104
00:05:48.580 --> 00:05:51.540
This stuff is hardware
that's really present.

105
00:05:51.540 --> 00:05:53.780
If I see sdb, sdc, sdd,

106
00:05:53.780 --> 00:05:57.860
I know I've got four drives, right,
and that they're real drives.

107
00:05:57.860 --> 00:06:00.830
It's not like the other one's
just a placeholder, so,

108
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:03.670
really a big change from
the older distributions.

109
00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:06.480
And by older,
I mean really like eight to ten years ago.

110
00:06:06.480 --> 00:06:09.410
So, it's definitely been
a while that we've had,

111
00:06:09.410 --> 00:06:13.660
the dynamic, hardware identification like
this, so really cool stuff, all right.

112
00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:16.260
Now, udev doesn't work by itself.

113
00:06:16.260 --> 00:06:18.813
It actually works in combination
with two other things.

114
00:06:18.813 --> 00:06:23.746
We have udev, the hal, H-A-L,

115
00:06:23.746 --> 00:06:26.880
and dbus, all right, or the dynamic bus.

116
00:06:26.880 --> 00:06:31.049
And these three things talk to each other
and they perform a different function.

117
00:06:31.049 --> 00:06:34.098
So udev identifies the hardware,
right, and

118
00:06:34.098 --> 00:06:37.319
it creates these mappings
that we can access it.

119
00:06:37.319 --> 00:06:40.080
hal is the hardware abstraction layer, and

120
00:06:40.080 --> 00:06:44.506
it allows udev to interact
with what's called the dbus.

121
00:06:44.506 --> 00:06:48.880
dbus is what actually communicates
with the software on our system.

122
00:06:48.880 --> 00:06:53.870
So if you launch a MP3 player, and
you hit play to play music, your MP3

123
00:06:53.870 --> 00:06:59.800
player uses the dbus to talk to the hal,
and it says hey, I'm trying to play music.

124
00:06:59.800 --> 00:07:04.950
And the hal then reaches out to
udev to find the music device,

125
00:07:04.950 --> 00:07:09.020
usually /dev/snd, which we'll see in here,
yeah, right there, snd.

126
00:07:09.020 --> 00:07:11.730
So that's like our generic sound device.

127
00:07:11.730 --> 00:07:14.520
And so then udev will provide that
connection, and then we're off and

128
00:07:14.520 --> 00:07:15.600
going and playing.

129
00:07:15.600 --> 00:07:18.571
So the three of them serve
a unique purpose, right,

130
00:07:18.571 --> 00:07:22.110
that all three together gives
us our hardware access.

131
00:07:22.110 --> 00:07:26.190
So let me bring up my notes to show
you kind of how I've written that out,

132
00:07:26.190 --> 00:07:29.280
is I kinda map it this way.

133
00:07:29.280 --> 00:07:32.320
udev talks to hal, and
it's a two-way communication.

134
00:07:32.320 --> 00:07:33.650
The hal can talk to udev.

135
00:07:33.650 --> 00:07:37.170
And hal talks to dbus, and
dbus talks back to the hal.

136
00:07:37.170 --> 00:07:40.080
So dbus is interacting with our software.

137
00:07:40.080 --> 00:07:42.660
udev is interacting with
our physical hardware.

138
00:07:42.660 --> 00:07:47.444
And the hal is kind of that intermediary,
the go-between of the systems, all right.

139
00:07:47.444 --> 00:07:49.279
Things weren't always like that.

140
00:07:49.279 --> 00:07:54.004
When we didn't have like the hal in place,
it was driver hell.

141
00:07:54.004 --> 00:07:56.311
I mean,
you had to have specialized drivers for

142
00:07:56.311 --> 00:07:58.512
almost every software
package that you ran.

143
00:07:58.512 --> 00:08:02.402
Now, we have the HAL,
the harbor obstruction layer.

144
00:08:02.402 --> 00:08:07.470
And so, our software no longer has to know
how to talk directly to the hardware.

145
00:08:07.470 --> 00:08:11.040
It just has to know how to talk to
the D bus and through it the HAL.

146
00:08:11.040 --> 00:08:15.480
And then the HAL, can use drivers
to access the actual hardware.

147
00:08:15.480 --> 00:08:19.310
And that makes it where the hardware
vendors just split the HAL, not software.

148
00:08:19.310 --> 00:08:22.550
And software vendors just have to
split the HAL and not hardware.

149
00:08:22.550 --> 00:08:24.350
So it gives us that separation.

150
00:08:24.350 --> 00:08:27.010
But these three things work together,
and for

151
00:08:27.010 --> 00:08:29.670
the most part we never
have to mess with them.

152
00:08:29.670 --> 00:08:32.190
They do their job and
they do it really well.

153
00:08:33.450 --> 00:08:37.110
There are times where you might have to
reach in there and mess with things, but

154
00:08:37.110 --> 00:08:41.120
for the most part we don't
really have to sweat it.

155
00:08:41.120 --> 00:08:45.100
Okay now the HAL, the hardware abstraction
layer, one of the things that it does

156
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:49.290
Is it creates a XML
representation of the hardware.

157
00:08:49.290 --> 00:08:53.900
So when udev is mapping things out,
it's not just mapping and saying,

158
00:08:53.900 --> 00:08:57.960
hey the sound card is tied to /dev/snd,
it's not stopping there, right?

159
00:08:57.960 --> 00:09:02.980
It's going on to provide a lot
more information as far as like,

160
00:09:02.980 --> 00:09:06.800
what registers, what memory registers that
system's using, what DMAs they're tied to,

161
00:09:06.800 --> 00:09:10.070
all that other kind of crazy stuff,
and we just don't see that, right?

162
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:11.040
Well, the HAL does.

163
00:09:11.040 --> 00:09:14.160
And I'll show you some commands here in
a little bit that'll show you how we can

164
00:09:14.160 --> 00:09:17.780
start to see some of that information,
that we've kind of manipulated or

165
00:09:17.780 --> 00:09:19.410
at least look at it to find out things.

166
00:09:20.660 --> 00:09:22.120
All right.

167
00:09:22.120 --> 00:09:27.610
Now, let's say that we have a device,
a hard drive or whatever that we hook up,

168
00:09:27.610 --> 00:09:32.330
and udev identifies it and
attaches a code here to it, right?

169
00:09:32.330 --> 00:09:37.110
And we don't like that code, and for
some reason we need to change it.

170
00:09:37.110 --> 00:09:40.520
Maybe I've got some software
that just demands I

171
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:45.310
have /devl/hda instead of /sda, okay.

172
00:09:45.310 --> 00:09:48.350
You can override the udelv mappings.

173
00:09:48.350 --> 00:09:53.240
Now in real life land it's something
you really rarely have to do.

174
00:09:53.240 --> 00:09:56.599
An example might be, I'm trying to think
of a real world one that I've done.

175
00:09:59.070 --> 00:09:59.880
I know one, Ronnie.

176
00:09:59.880 --> 00:10:03.840
Ronnie and I both,
we work with Cisco equipment a lot.

177
00:10:03.840 --> 00:10:06.175
And we use those little USB
serial adapters, right?

178
00:10:06.175 --> 00:10:07.480
>> Mm-hm.

179
00:10:07.480 --> 00:10:09.990
Most laptops these days
don't have serial ports.

180
00:10:09.990 --> 00:10:11.690
Do I have mine?

181
00:10:11.690 --> 00:10:13.770
I don't have mine.

182
00:10:13.770 --> 00:10:15.950
Anyhow, most laptops don't
have serial ports, but

183
00:10:15.950 --> 00:10:18.750
to connect to this console equipment,
we need a serial port.

184
00:10:18.750 --> 00:10:21.490
We buy these little usb
to serial adapters and

185
00:10:21.490 --> 00:10:25.570
you stick them on your laptop and
your laptop picks them up as a usb device.

186
00:10:26.710 --> 00:10:30.590
And then if your Linux system
recognizes it might map it and

187
00:10:30.590 --> 00:10:32.150
map it as a USB device.

188
00:10:32.150 --> 00:10:33.930
But you need it as a serial port.

189
00:10:33.930 --> 00:10:38.030
You want it to be a serial port that
you can communicate with basically,

190
00:10:38.030 --> 00:10:38.980
a TTY in your system.

191
00:10:38.980 --> 00:10:41.900
And so it might not map those properly.

192
00:10:41.900 --> 00:10:45.520
Now the one I own wouldn't be a good
example cuz the one I have works.

193
00:10:45.520 --> 00:10:48.090
But if you have one that just
doesn't get recognized properly,

194
00:10:48.090 --> 00:10:50.250
you might need to override it.

195
00:10:50.250 --> 00:10:53.250
Well, udev when you plug in devices

196
00:10:53.250 --> 00:10:57.050
has a series of rules that it
uses to map things together.

197
00:10:57.050 --> 00:10:59.720
And you can see those,
they're in your etc folder.

198
00:10:59.720 --> 00:11:06.384
If I got into /etc/udev.

199
00:11:08.884 --> 00:11:12.373
All right,
in here you'll see a couple of things and

200
00:11:12.373 --> 00:11:16.510
the one I'm looking for
is that folder right there rules.d.

201
00:11:16.510 --> 00:11:17.051
All right.

202
00:11:17.051 --> 00:11:18.328
It's a folder and

203
00:11:18.328 --> 00:11:24.384
inside of it you'll see the configuration
files that identify how we name devices.

204
00:11:24.384 --> 00:11:25.250
Okay.

205
00:11:25.250 --> 00:11:31.910
You'll see some of these in here that
are for PCMCIA or pc cards for laptops.

206
00:11:31.910 --> 00:11:35.320
We've got CD for our CD drives.

207
00:11:35.320 --> 00:11:38.820
Net persistent net rules for
our network adapters.

208
00:11:38.820 --> 00:11:42.190
You've got kernel and
rules right over there.

209
00:11:42.190 --> 00:11:46.434
I've got VMware installed so
see how I've VMware scuzzy dev rules.

210
00:11:46.434 --> 00:11:49.460
Those are so
that my SCSI hard drives that I attach

211
00:11:49.460 --> 00:11:53.020
will show up as SDA instead
of some kind of virtual disk.

212
00:11:53.020 --> 00:11:55.600
Alsa rules, those are for the sound cards.

213
00:11:55.600 --> 00:12:00.970
And so each of these are for basically
setting how we name those devices.

214
00:12:00.970 --> 00:12:05.290
And you can do overrides, right.

215
00:12:05.290 --> 00:12:07.540
Another maybe real world
example we might have.

216
00:12:08.780 --> 00:12:10.850
Maybe at two network
adapters in your computer.

217
00:12:10.850 --> 00:12:14.520
Right, one was identified as eth0,
or ethernet 0, and

218
00:12:14.520 --> 00:12:17.530
the other one was
identified as ethernet 1.

219
00:12:17.530 --> 00:12:21.150
Right, so F0, F1, those are the two
adapters that were on your system.

220
00:12:21.150 --> 00:12:23.300
And then over time you
decide you don't need one.

221
00:12:23.300 --> 00:12:27.290
And so you pull one out, and
the one you pull out was ETH0.

222
00:12:27.290 --> 00:12:30.990
Well the one that you're
left with is ETH1.

223
00:12:30.990 --> 00:12:34.410
Well you decide, I don't want that

02:03:19.192 --> 02:03:22.122
And that, like I said,
that may not be what we want.

2206
02:03:22.122 --> 02:03:25.612
So if we wanna shut down and actually have
it power off, that's where we need to do

2207
02:03:25.612 --> 02:03:32.530
a dash lowercase h dash capital H or a
dash, shoot, what's the other one, dash P.

2208
02:03:32.530 --> 02:03:37.390
To actually say power down,
based on what our system supports.

2209
02:03:37.390 --> 02:03:39.020
Most systems support all three,

2210
02:03:39.020 --> 02:03:43.180
so I usually just kinds of
default to shutdown -h.

2211
02:03:43.180 --> 02:03:46.322
So if I do shutdown -h now,

2212
02:03:46.322 --> 02:03:52.100
that means shutdown and
halt right now, okay?

2213
02:03:52.100 --> 02:03:54.033
So don't bother with single user mode.

2214
02:03:54.033 --> 02:03:58.410
And if I run that, there it goes shutting
down and we should see it halt the system.

2215
02:04:01.696 --> 02:04:02.705
Anytime now.

2216
02:04:02.705 --> 02:04:04.355
[LAUGH] There we go.

2217
02:04:04.355 --> 02:04:07.455
See, it's actually halting the system and
then off we go.

2218
02:04:07.455 --> 02:04:09.035
Now, if that doesn't work.

2219
02:04:09.035 --> 02:04:11.780
I used to see this on
laptops all the time.

2220
02:04:11.780 --> 02:04:14.545
It would halt and then on the screen,
it would just sit there.

2221
02:04:14.545 --> 02:04:18.970
Displaying the Linux halt statement, and
it would sit there forever and run your

2222
02:04:18.970 --> 02:04:22.730
battery dead, and you'd be really angry
when you got to wherever you were going.

2223
02:04:22.730 --> 02:04:25.430
So that's where some of the other
options come into play.

2224
02:04:25.430 --> 02:04:26.910
And so on a lot of older laptops,

2225
02:04:26.910 --> 02:04:31.000
they had to do shutdown -p to tell it,
I actually want you to power off.

2226
02:04:31.000 --> 02:04:33.767
Don't just freeze, actually go
the rest of the way and power off.

2227
02:04:33.767 --> 02:04:37.078
But if your system's not supported,
then you may not have that option,

2228
02:04:37.078 --> 02:04:38.443
you might not be able to do it.

2229
02:04:43.233 --> 02:04:47.150
All right, so shutdown-r will do a reboot.

2230
02:04:47.150 --> 02:04:51.210
There is an alias for that also,
which is the reboot command, right?

2231
02:04:51.210 --> 02:04:56.100
Which is the same thing as shutdown -r if
I pull up that file, or the man file for

2232
02:04:56.100 --> 02:04:57.940
that, you can see reboot.

2233
02:04:57.940 --> 02:04:59.433
It doesn't take a ton of options.

2234
02:04:59.433 --> 02:05:04.729
-force, -poweroff, -wtmp only, -reboot,

2235
02:05:04.729 --> 02:05:12.870
-force, that's really just like
basically forcing your system to reboot.

2236
02:05:12.870 --> 02:05:14.030
I hate to use the word force,

2237
02:05:14.030 --> 02:05:16.670
I'm having a hard time thinking
of an alternate word there.

2238
02:05:16.670 --> 02:05:19.200
But basically it skips over
the shutdown process and

2239
02:05:19.200 --> 02:05:20.950
just says no matter what, reboot.

2240
02:05:20.950 --> 02:05:22.290
Just do it.

2241
02:05:22.290 --> 02:05:24.200
Power off, on the other hand,
makes it halt.

2242
02:05:24.200 --> 02:05:25.555
And that's basically shut down.

2243
02:05:25.555 --> 02:05:29.107
Reboot -p is really
the same as shutdown -p.

2244
02:05:29.107 --> 02:05:32.446
So, we don't normally feed all
that much into the reboot command.

2245
02:05:32.446 --> 02:05:36.522
When you look at it,
you don't even have to give it a time.

2246
02:05:36.522 --> 02:05:39.239
If you just type reboot,
it's going to reboot.

2247
02:05:39.239 --> 02:05:43.590
So, if I punch that in,
there it goes and it's rebooting.

2248
02:05:43.590 --> 02:05:46.750
If you wanna reboot with a timer,
you need to do shutdown -r, and

2249
02:05:46.750 --> 02:05:47.530
then you can give it a time.

2250
02:05:50.150 --> 02:05:51.360
Speaking of time,

2251
02:05:51.360 --> 02:05:54.780
I mentioned how you can set it to
five minutes from now or whatever.

2252
02:05:54.780 --> 02:05:57.290
You can set it to a specific
time if you want.

2253
02:05:57.290 --> 02:06:00.880
Maybe I made a change to my system,
and I know it needs a reboot, but

2254
02:06:00.880 --> 02:06:03.280
I don't wanna do it in the middle of
the day while people are in the system.

2255
02:06:04.350 --> 02:06:07.700
So maybe I want the computer to reboot
at 3:00 AM, when nobody's in there,

2256
02:06:07.700 --> 02:06:08.200
all right?

2257
02:06:08.200 --> 02:06:10.522
Well, I don't want to come
up to the office at 3:00 AM.

2258
02:06:10.522 --> 02:06:13.358
Heck, I don't even wanna wake up and
remote in at 3:00 AM,

2259
02:06:13.358 --> 02:06:14.760
I just want it to be automatic.

2260
02:06:14.760 --> 02:06:20.571
So what you can do is you
can run shutdown -r and

2261
02:06:20.571 --> 02:06:24.003
then specify 3:00 AM.

2262
02:06:24.003 --> 02:06:29.135
Okay, so I'm gonna put 03:00,
it does use the military time clock or

2263
02:06:29.135 --> 02:06:33.600
the universal 24 hour time code,
whatever we wanna call it.

2264
02:06:33.600 --> 02:06:36.670
So I'm saying go ahead and
reboot at 3:00 AM.

2265
02:06:36.670 --> 02:06:39.530
And I'll stick my ampersand on
the end to run it in the background.

2266
02:06:39.530 --> 02:06:41.367
And now it's scheduling that reboot.

2267
02:06:41.367 --> 02:06:45.407
The system is going down for
a reboot in 743 minutes.

2268
02:06:45.407 --> 02:06:48.309
So that's in a little while.

2269
02:06:48.309 --> 02:06:48.902
>> Yeah.

2270
02:06:48.902 --> 02:06:54.243
>> So, now I can wait 743 minutes.

2271
02:06:54.243 --> 02:06:54.823
>> There you go.

2272
02:06:54.823 --> 02:06:55.462
>> Maybe not.

2273
02:06:55.462 --> 02:06:59.200
All right, so [LAUGH] I don't have
that kind of patience on my hands but

2274
02:06:59.200 --> 02:07:02.730
you can schedule for a time and
that's a really nice thing.

2275
02:07:02.730 --> 02:07:06.460
Just remember you can always do
shutdown -c and that'll cancel it.

2276
02:07:06.460 --> 02:07:10.440
You cannot schedule more than one
shutdown at the same time, all right?

2277
02:07:10.440 --> 02:07:12.743
If you want that,
you'll have to create Cron jobs, and

2278
02:07:12.743 --> 02:07:15.746
we haven't learned about Cron yet,
so we'll just say you can't do it.

2279
02:07:15.746 --> 02:07:19.424
[LAUGH] There's always
a way to do something.

2280
02:07:19.424 --> 02:07:20.830
But using the shutdown command,

2281
02:07:20.830 --> 02:07:22.990
you can only have one
shutdown scheduled at a time.

2282
02:07:24.390 --> 02:07:27.314
All right, another useful command.

2283
02:07:27.314 --> 02:07:30.961
We talked about the file
system health check, fsck.

2284
02:07:30.961 --> 02:07:34.945
And how when you reboot after
a certain amount of mounts or

2285
02:07:34.945 --> 02:07:40.093
after a certain amount of time,
it'll check the file system for errors.

2286
02:07:40.093 --> 02:07:46.400
And we can run fsck-a and it'll check all
of our systems, unless they're mounted.

2287
02:07:46.400 --> 02:07:52.050
So what if we want to force a file
system check of our root mount point,

2288
02:07:52.050 --> 02:07:53.630
which is always mounted, right?

2289
02:07:53.630 --> 02:07:58.496
Well, for that,
there's a special shutdown command

2290
02:07:58.496 --> 02:08:03.704
that we can use,
you can do a shutdown -r -F, all right?

2291
02:08:03.704 --> 02:08:05.280
That says reboot and

2292
02:08:05.280 --> 02:08:09.845
on the next boot, force fsck to run,
and it'll check the hard drive.

2293
02:08:09.845 --> 02:08:12.262
So that's a good way to
force that check to happen,

2294
02:08:12.262 --> 02:08:15.315
and ensure that your drives
are healthy if you're not certain.

2295
02:08:15.315 --> 02:08:18.490
Because it does it at boot time,
they can catch it before all those drives

2296
02:08:18.490 --> 02:08:21.889
are mounted or it can catch it while
the drives are mounted read only, right?

2297
02:08:21.889 --> 02:08:24.129
So if I run that, I didn't specify a time.

2298
02:08:24.129 --> 02:08:28.735
So if I run that, shutdown -r -F now.

2299
02:08:28.735 --> 02:08:34.380
Now it's gonna reboot and when it boots,
it should run the file system check.

2300
02:08:34.380 --> 02:08:37.919
Now my file system's only 20 gigs in size,
it's pretty small.

2301
02:08:37.919 --> 02:08:40.403
So the check will happen pretty fast.

2302
02:08:42.668 --> 02:08:44.966
But, let's see, here it goes.

2303
02:08:44.966 --> 02:08:49.730
And CentOS is gonna cover it
up with its crazy blue line.

2304
02:08:49.730 --> 02:08:50.770
Which don't we hit escape?

2305
02:08:50.770 --> 02:08:51.580
There we go.

2306
02:08:51.580 --> 02:08:54.290
And it's already gone by I just missed it,
but yeah,

2307
02:08:54.290 --> 02:08:56.430
I did the file system check
right there above that.

2308
02:08:56.430 --> 02:09:00.170
I didn't hit escape in time to
actually see the verbose boot.

2309
02:09:00.170 --> 02:09:04.180
And I don't think I mentioned that
in the show, is that a lot of

2310
02:09:04.180 --> 02:09:09.170
Linux systems have pretty startup screens
now, like Ubuntu and Red Hat and stuff.

2311
02:09:09.170 --> 02:09:12.190
And if you press escape on your keyboard,

2312
02:09:12.190 --> 02:09:13.960
it'll make it where you
can see what's going on.

2313
02:09:13.960 --> 02:09:15.620
Let's do that again.

2314
02:09:15.620 --> 02:09:19.760
And I just want you guys to see that it
is actually checking that file system.

2315
02:09:19.760 --> 02:09:20.761
So we'll let it reboot.

2316
02:09:24.651 --> 02:09:26.280
Oops.

2317
02:09:26.280 --> 02:09:30.050
Pressed too many keys as I am won't to do.

2318
02:09:30.050 --> 02:09:30.870
There we go.

2319
02:09:30.870 --> 02:09:32.600
All right.
So here it goes booting up and

2320
02:09:32.600 --> 02:09:35.410
you're welcome to CentOS and
it's starting to recognize my hardware and

2321
02:09:35.410 --> 02:09:38.820
there's the file system check right
there and it's already off the screen.

2322
02:09:38.820 --> 02:09:43.170
You know, 20 gigs is very, very small so
it's able to check those very quickly and

2323
02:09:43.170 --> 02:09:45.370
then move on.

2324
02:09:45.370 --> 02:09:48.160
I did have one failure there for
HGFS which I'm not using.

2325
02:09:48.160 --> 02:09:51.230
I'm not sure why it's even starting that,
must be part of the default install.

2326
02:09:52.830 --> 02:09:54.000
Let's see, what else do we have?

2327
02:09:54.000 --> 02:09:55.880
I think that's really about it.

2328
02:09:58.850 --> 02:10:00.600
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, that's about it.

2329
02:10:00.600 --> 02:10:04.910
So just remember, like doing a shutdown
really is like calling init zero.

2330
02:10:04.910 --> 02:10:07.020
I guess I could do that,
just for the fun of it,

2331
02:10:07.020 --> 02:10:09.530
since this is not a production system.

2332
02:10:09.530 --> 02:10:12.820
I wouldn't do it in a production system,
but if you do init zero,

2333
02:10:12.820 --> 02:10:17.260
that's basically saying shut down and
do it right now, and

2334
02:10:17.260 --> 02:10:19.500
it's not necessarily gonna do
it in the cleanest manner.

2335
02:10:19.500 --> 02:10:23.800
So when it goes through,
it will at least run the rc0.d scripts,

2336
02:10:23.800 --> 02:10:25.910
which tells it to gracefully shut down.

2337
02:10:25.910 --> 02:10:28.347
So it'll churn through,
and that'll knock it out.

2338
02:10:30.386 --> 02:10:34.557
All right, well I think that pretty
much sums it up for the boot process and

2339
02:10:34.557 --> 02:10:35.510
the run levels.

2340
02:10:35.510 --> 02:10:39.640

why I wanted to save that for the end.

02:10:39.640 --> 02:10:42.370

it in the very beginning when you hadn't

2342
02:10:42.370 --> 02:10:44.100

things that are going on.

2343
02:10:44.100 --> 02:10:46.310

02:11:47.010 --> 02:11:49.880
All right, well, signing out for

34
00:01:50.360 --> 00:01:52.480
a way of organizing the folders.

35
00:01:52.480 --> 00:01:57.020
In the early days of Linux, remember

36
00:01:57.020 --> 00:02:01.290
All the other stuff around it is created

37

You can do that, distros can choose

45

54
00:03:02.610 --> 00:03:06.330

56
00:03:12.270 --> 00:03:14.270

57
00:03:14.270 --> 00:03:16.455
And that's where your user

58
00:03:16.455 --> 00:03:19.572
So that's where my
personal files would go.

59
00:03:19.572 --> 00:03:23.720
There's also /ruth which I don't
think they've put on there.

60
00:03:23.720 --> 00:03:24.390
Yeah.

61
00:03:24.390 --> 00:03:28.000

it's outside of /home.

62
00:03:28.000 --> 00:03:31.990
So every user account we create
will get a folder inside of /home,

63
00:03:31.990 --> 00:03:35.510
but root that user gets
a folder that's just /root.

64
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:39.010
It's not actually in the home folder,
all right.

65
00:03:39.010 --> 00:03:42.510
/etc is another big one, that's where
all of our configuration files are, and

66
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:44.480
etc is just sort for etchetera.

67
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:50.680
All the various configurations in system

68
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:54.960

text files, and so when you look in there,

00:03:54.960 --> 00:03:56.990

70
00:03:56.990 --> 00:03:59.730

00:04:07.970 --> 00:04:10.090

75
00:04:10.090 --> 00:04:13.390
And /bin, those are user binaries

76
00:04:14.420 --> 00:04:19.277

77

00:04:21.810 --> 00:04:25.920

00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:30.610

89
00:04:56.920 --> 00:04:59.410
When we do PSAUX, right.

90
00:04:59.410 --> 00:05:03.280
And we list all of our processes, it's
really looking into that proc folder and

91
00:05:03.280 --> 00:05:05.800

92
00:05:05.800 --> 00:05:09.070
And every time a program runs, it's
supposed to register a pID file in there,

93
00:05:09.070 --> 00:05:13.840
so that's what's in the prog folder,
/bar, right.

94
00:05:13.840 --> 00:05:16.140
This is where we have our variable files.

95
00:05:16.140 --> 00:05:19.410
You'll hear variable or various,
people have different names for it, and

96
00:05:19.410 --> 00:05:21.360
I don't mean variables like
programming variables.

97
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:26.010
I just mean that, when you have two
servers that are running CentOS 6.5 for

98
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:28.310
the most part they're identical, right.

99
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:31.150
They have the same set of files,
they're both running the same OS.

100
00:05:31.150 --> 00:05:32.710
What is it that makes them unique?

101
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:36.114
The things that make them unique
are typically in /var, right.

102
00:05:36.114 --> 00:05:39.530
/home may also be unique,
but /var definitely.

103
00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:41.170
So if I'm running a web server,

104
00:05:41.170 --> 00:05:44.480
all of my website files will
typically go in /var/ www.

105
00:05:44.480 --> 00:05:45.210
If we're running Apache.

106
00:05:46.440 --> 00:05:50.150
If you're running a different web browser,
it might go somewhere else.

107
00:05:50.150 --> 00:05:54.640
So you might have five web servers,
which are all basically identical, but

108
00:05:54.640 --> 00:05:59.515
then the web pages they host
are different Inside a slash bar.

109
00:05:59.515 --> 00:06:01.735
/tmp, that's temporary files, right.

110
00:06:01.735 --> 00:06:03.815
Just things that we're not going
to be using for very long.

111

53

62

63

71
00:03:34.430 --> 00:03:36.050

72
00:03:36.050 --> 00:03:37.480
DF gives you the overall numbers.

73

74
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:44.200

75

76
00:03:47.430 --> 00:03:49.340

77

78
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:56.310
And it's nice because we
can use this to figure out

79
00:03:56.310 --> 00:03:58.600
where our space is being consumed.

80
00:03:58.600 --> 00:03:59.200
Okay.

81
00:03:59.200 --> 00:04:03.880
So when I look at a folder,

83

85
00:04:15.320 --> 00:04:18.330

86
00:04:18.330 --> 00:04:21.040
Now what I don't get is

87
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:23.800
it doesn't tell me how much
all these files are together.

88
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:27.200

00:04:27.200 --> 00:04:30.130

90
00:04:30.130 --> 00:04:31.640
So df is like disk free.

91
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:33.720

92
00:04:33.720 --> 00:04:36.320

95

00:04:47.740 --> 00:04:52.700

98
00:04:52.700 --> 00:04:57.160
And you get a nice little list, but

99
00:04:57.160 --> 00:04:59.330
I know it kinda looks like it does,

00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:04.430
So I don't get a great set of data

a little bit of targeting, all right.

00:05:12.760 --> 00:05:16.340
These are my three favorite options.

105
00:05:16.340 --> 00:05:19.600
C means to give me a total.

106
00:05:19.600 --> 00:05:24.070
Add up all of the files and

107
00:05:24.070 --> 00:05:27.140
H says use human readable numbers.

108
00:05:27.140 --> 00:05:28.560
So don't give them to me in bytes.

109
00:05:28.560 --> 00:05:30.958
Give them to me in megs or

110
00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:34.984
And if I run it like that, now I get
the same basic pay, except the numbers

00:05:34.984 --> 00:05:39.406

112
00:05:39.406 --> 00:05:42.260
and I guess I was getting

113
00:05:42.260 --> 00:05:46.780
So 298 megabytes here in my folder alone,

114
00:05:46.780 --> 00:05:50.650
We can combine that with S, and

115
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:54.460
I'm not normally so concerned about

00:05:54.460 --> 00:05:57.080
I'm more concerned about

117
00:05:57.080 --> 00:06:00.960
And so if you run du-chs,
you can run it and

00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:04.700

119
00:06:04.700 --> 00:06:09.230
So I can see that my folder that I'm

120
00:06:10.730 --> 00:06:12.010
And you can point it anywhere.

121
00:06:12.010 --> 00:06:14.240
I can say look at /home, right.

122
00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:18.220
Take a look at /home and

00:06:18.220 --> 00:06:24.180

124
00:06:24.180 --> 00:06:27.380
Or I could point it at sbin, right.

125
00:06:28.530 --> 00:06:29.990
And I can see it's only 15 megs.

126
00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:33.340
So you can start pointing at
different locations at your drive and

127
00:06:33.340 --> 00:06:35.140
finding out how big those folders are.

128
00:06:35.140 --> 00:06:38.990
That's really useful to be able to find
out where your space is being eaten up.

129
00:06:40.700 --> 00:06:46.224
So if we combine that with df, we can get
a good idea of where our storage is going.

130
00:06:47.868 --> 00:06:51.036
All right,
now normally we format our disks,

131
00:06:51.036 --> 00:06:54.620
we mount them to a mount point,

132
00:06:54.620 --> 00:06:58.960

We specify that.

When we formatted that other

00:07:48.048 --> 00:07:55.090

00:07:55.090 --> 00:07:56.640
Which ever comes first.

148
00:07:56.640 --> 00:07:59.550
Okay.

00:07:59.550 --> 00:08:00.168

And so it's basically saying
every 180 reboots or six months.

151
00:08:04.488 --> 00:08:05.949
Whichever comes first, right?

I think it was 180 that was the default,

00:08:08.075 --> 00:08:09.212
it might be a different number.

154
00:08:09.212 --> 00:08:13.070
But, it was basically saying it would

155
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:15.210
Well, what if we don't wanna wait for
the interval?

156
00:08:15.210 --> 00:08:18.730
What if we wanna scan a disk for
errors right now?

157
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:21.170
I'm seeing some odd
behavior out of a disk and

158
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:23.560
I wanna figure out what's going on, okay?

159
00:08:23.560 --> 00:08:27.510
But we can force that disk
check whenever we want using

160
00:08:28.680 --> 00:08:34.720
the F-S-C-K utility and that's
the file system check utility, right?

161
00:08:34.720 --> 00:08:38.900
When it said hey, I'm gonna check your
disk every six months, it just meant that

162
00:08:38.900 --> 00:08:42.240
if six months goes by and we haven't
checked, the next time you reboot,

163
00:08:42.240 --> 00:08:47.820
when you boot, it will run FSCK and
it will check your disk, right?

164
00:08:47.820 --> 00:08:50.780
Now, FSCK was designed for EXT two.

165
00:08:50.780 --> 00:08:52.230
It's been around a long time.

166
00:08:52.230 --> 00:08:56.650
But, we can use it to scan other file
systems too, it's really flexible.

167
00:08:56.650 --> 00:08:59.260
In fact,
what it normally does when you run it,

168
00:08:59.260 --> 00:09:03.480
it looks at your file system table,
your fstab file, and

169
00:09:03.480 --> 00:09:07.550
it looks in there and
tells you what file system everything is.

170
00:09:07.550 --> 00:09:14.442
Remember, that fstab file,
if we do more slash /etc/fstab, all right.

171
00:09:14.442 --> 00:09:16.350
There's my file systems.

172
00:09:16.350 --> 00:09:19.570
And it shows in there what
each one is formatted, so

173
00:09:19.570 --> 00:09:24.132
I can see like ext4 or swap temfs,

174
00:09:24.132 --> 00:09:29.980
devpts, sysfs, proc, each of these
are different file systems and

175
00:09:29.980 --> 00:09:34.470
FSCK knows whether or not it can check
these and what it can work with.

176
00:09:34.470 --> 00:09:38.360
Also remember when we look at this,
these last two numbers.

177
00:09:38.360 --> 00:09:40.600
The first one is saying whether or
not we back the drive up, but

178
00:09:40.600 --> 00:09:43.750
the second one is saying whether
we should check it for errors.

179
00:09:43.750 --> 00:09:48.520
So if I run fsck, I can point it
right at my boot drive here, and

180
00:09:48.520 --> 00:09:49.750
it's gonna scan it.

181
00:09:49.750 --> 00:09:54.180
Or I could point it at this other, I'm
sorry, my root drive, or my boot drive,

182
00:09:54.180 --> 00:09:55.290
and it's gonna scan it.

183
00:09:55.290 --> 00:09:58.780
But, if I point it at my swap or
the shm, or any of these other places,

184
00:09:58.780 --> 00:10:03.558
if not in a scan mode,
because they have that 0 at the end.

185
00:10:03.558 --> 00:10:08.380
If you wanna check all of your disks,
the easiest way to use fsck is

186
00:10:08.380 --> 00:10:12.510
just to run fsck dash and a capital a.

187
00:10:12.510 --> 00:10:15.000
That capital a says check
all my file systems.

188
00:10:15.000 --> 00:10:19.030
Just read f stab and whatever it says can
be checked, just go ahead and check it.

189
00:10:19.030 --> 00:10:20.970
So, if you're just doing
routine maintenance,

190
00:10:20.970 --> 00:10:25.180
if you're doing a scheduled job to do
the scan once a month or whatever, that's

191
00:10:25.180 --> 00:10:29.930
usually the command that we run, and we
don't worry too much more about it, right?

192
00:10:29.930 --> 00:10:33.910
But we can do a lot more if we want,
so for example,

193
00:10:33.910 --> 00:10:38.800
I could say fsck dash
t to specify what type

194
00:10:38.800 --> 00:10:44.850
of disk I'm scanning and then I could
point to where that disk is mounted.

195
00:10:44.850 --> 00:10:47.610
I'm sorry, not where it's mounted,
I gotta point to the partition.

196
00:10:47.610 --> 00:10:51.151
So, we'd have to say
/dev/mapper/VolGroup-lv_root.

197
00:10:51.151 --> 00:10:56.376
If I wanna scan my root mount point,

198
00:10:56.376 --> 00:11:00.040
then I can scan that way.

199
00:11:00.040 --> 00:11:06.250
If I didn't use the lvm, then I would
point to /dev, /sda1 or wherever it was.

200
00:11:06.250 --> 00:11:10.890
So I'm gonna do this scan here, saying
it's the xt4, and go ahead and scan it.

201
00:11:10.890 --> 00:11:14.520
Now, it probably would have figured out
that it was the xt4 on it's own, and

202
00:11:14.520 --> 00:11:17.850
if we'd done fsck-a it
definitely would have.

203
00:11:17.850 --> 00:11:20.780
But, this will just basically
reach out there and run a scan.

204
00:11:20.780 --> 00:11:23.950
Now, it's gonna give me a warning
here saying it's mounted.

205
00:11:23.950 --> 00:11:26.470
You can't scan a disk that's mounted,

206
00:11:26.470 --> 00:11:29.250
because it's in use by
the operating system.

207
00:11:29.250 --> 00:11:32.570
That's why these scans
normally happen at boot time.

208
00:11:32.570 --> 00:11:36.220
That's why we have that whole
automated system in place.

209
00:11:36.220 --> 00:11:40.430
But if we had a disk that we had
created after the fact and mounted.

210
00:11:40.430 --> 00:11:42.020
Then we could run this.

211
00:11:42.020 --> 00:11:48.609
In fact, do I still have,
don't I have sdb?

212
00:11:48.609 --> 00:11:54.735
Yeah, so I've got sdb and
it looks like I got a partition on it.

00:11:54.735 --> 00:11:56.680
Let me just make sure that I do.

214
00:11:58.680 --> 00:12:00.850
Yes, so it's got a Linux partition on it.

215
00:12:00.850 --> 00:12:05.651
And, I'll just format it real quick.

216
00:12:09.985 --> 00:12:15.390
So, I'm just gonna format it, I'm using
mkfs.ext4 to format it as a ext4 disk.

217
00:12:16.402 --> 00:12:20.260
And then, I think I mounted as
videos the other day, right?

218
00:12:20.260 --> 00:12:21.777
It's still there, good.

219
00:12:21.777 --> 00:12:27.580
So, now I'm just gonna
mount that to videos and

220
00:12:27.580 --> 00:12:31.942
now, I can go in and start to use it.

221
00:12:31.942 --> 00:12:37.307
If I try to scan it, so
I'm just gonna try and

222
00:12:37.307 --> 00:12:40.942

01:57:13.680 --> 01:57:15.250

02:01:43.550 --> 02:01:46.440

01:40:27.930 --> 01:40:32.090
find somebody who needs that help,
when you can take away that obstacle and

1935
01:40:32.090 --> 01:40:35.510
let them use a computer,
that's big deal, that really is.

1936
01:40:35.510 --> 01:40:40.290
So, we'll see other options in here
like our Keyboard accessibility options.

1937
01:40:40.290 --> 01:40:43.422
Here we can go in and manually, not just
turn the options on, but tweak them.

1938
01:40:43.422 --> 01:40:48.380
So like Slow Keys, how long do you have
to hold the key for before it registers?

1939
01:40:48.380 --> 01:40:52.288
Or Bounce Keys, how long do you wait
to invalidate a double press, right?

1940
01:40:52.288 --> 01:40:57.490
Cuz that can get annoying if you're typing
a word like bookkeeper that has double Os,

1941
01:40:57.490 --> 01:41:00.500
double Ks, double Es all in a row, right.

1942
01:41:00.500 --> 01:41:04.160
If you've got Bounce Keys turned on it's
frustrating to type a word like that.

1943
01:41:04.160 --> 01:41:05.690
So, adjusting those values.

1944
01:41:05.690 --> 01:41:07.930
You've also got things like Mouse Keys.

1945
01:41:07.930 --> 01:41:11.320
See how I've got Pointer can be
controlled using the keypad?

1946
01:41:11.320 --> 01:41:15.080
That lets you use the arrow keys on your
keypad to move the mouse pointer instead

1947
01:41:15.080 --> 01:41:16.000
of using your mouse.

1948
01:41:16.000 --> 01:41:20.291
That's a neat feature,
if a mouse is not something you wanna use.

1949
01:41:21.450 --> 01:41:22.800
You can also do Typing Break.

1950
01:41:22.800 --> 01:41:25.780
This one I've never used,
I think it's more for controlling kids.

1951
01:41:25.780 --> 01:41:30.810
But if you're worried about fatigue,
if you don't want to

1952
01:41:30.810 --> 01:41:33.890

too long, you can set it to lock

1953
01:41:33.890 --> 01:41:37.050
your workstation after a certain period
of time and hold it locked for a while.

1954
01:41:37.050 --> 01:41:42.870
So basically enforcing breaks so that
you don't wear yourself out, all right?

1955
01:41:42.870 --> 01:41:44.570
You'll see a lot of other options in here.

1956
01:41:44.570 --> 01:41:47.190
Really it is just a ton of options.

1957
01:41:47.190 --> 01:41:49.780
And so it's a matter of finding
the ones that are right for

1958
01:41:49.780 --> 01:41:52.050
the scenario that you need.

1959
01:41:52.050 --> 01:41:56.470
>> Having that one mouse one where you can

1960
01:41:56.470 --> 01:42:00.700
keys, I find that at times on my XPS,

1961
01:42:00.700 --> 01:42:02.126

1962

>> [LAUGH] Yeah, the touch pad on there.

1964
01:42:04.280 --> 01:42:04.970
On this one.
>> Yeah.

1965
01:42:04.970 --> 01:42:09.050
It just goes to show these assistive
technologies, they're for everyone.

1966
01:42:09.050 --> 01:42:10.180
Anybody can benefit from these.

1967
01:42:10.180 --> 01:42:14.130
Anybody who is having difficulties
interacting with that desktop.

1968
01:42:14.130 --> 01:42:17.810
Because just because there's
a common use scenario

1969
01:42:17.810 --> 01:42:20.020
doesn't mean that's the use
scenario that fits for you.

1970
01:42:20.020 --> 01:42:22.790
You may need to adjust
things to meet your needs.

1971
01:42:22.790 --> 01:42:23.630
All right.

1972
01:42:23.630 --> 01:42:27.180
So those are the basics of
the assistive technologies.

1973
01:42:27.180 --> 01:42:28.720

1974

1975

There's a lot of great websites out there
that catalog different software that's

1976

1977
01:42:35.770 --> 01:42:39.420
Don't ever feel like you shouldn't
be able to use a computer.

1978
01:42:39.420 --> 01:42:42.419
There's the tools to make it happen, it's

1979

1980

1981

it can definitely be done.

1983

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don tackle Linux administrative tasks through the CLI. These tasks include managing user and group accounts and the password database. They take a look at setting up scheduled tasks using cron jobs and the 'at' command. Because Linux Systems may be located and relocated to different places in the world, they show the locale and time zone settings. They also talk about the importance of time synchronization for computer systems and how to configure NTP.
episodes.title: Administrative Tasks

44

Today, we're gonna look at
that in a little more depth.

45
00:02:23.295 --> 00:02:27.050
There's some things that we need to

46
00:02:27.050 --> 00:02:31.300

assign people and various things there.

47
00:02:31.300 --> 00:02:33.740
So that is an important thing for
us to understand, and

48
00:02:33.740 --> 00:02:36.040
that is where we're going
to start off today.

49
00:02:36.040 --> 00:02:37.030
>> That's great.

50
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:39.940
>> So, just to kind of rehash
a little bit of some of the things

51
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:44.430
we talked about before, when we access
a file there are permissions and

52
00:02:44.430 --> 00:02:47.910
the permissions apply to
one of three things, right.

53
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:52.090
They apply to,
the user who created the file or folder.

54
00:02:52.090 --> 00:02:53.910
Right.
So, the user created it.

55
00:02:53.910 --> 00:02:55.140
They're basically the owner.

56
00:02:55.140 --> 00:02:58.640
And then you got the group
assigned to the file.

57
00:02:58.640 --> 00:03:02.490
Anybody in that group is allowed
to have certain permissions.

58
00:03:02.490 --> 00:03:04.420
And then there's the others.

59
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:05.720
Right.
Everybody else.

60
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:09.560
Anybody else and the access they get,
so I just remember it as U-G-O,

61
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:13.760
user, group, others, right, those
are the three permissions we set on files.

62
00:03:13.760 --> 00:03:17.370
Well, for users to be effective,
we've gotta have users.

63
00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:20.680
If root is all we have,
then we're not gonna get very far in life.

64
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:23.860
And then if we wanna make use of groups,
well we've gotta create some.

65
00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:26.530
And sure, there's some system
groups that are created but,

66
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:28.450
they're really not designed for us to use.

67
00:03:28.450 --> 00:03:30.020
They're designed for the system to use.

68
00:03:30.020 --> 00:03:31.070
They're system groups.

69
00:03:31.070 --> 00:03:34.210
So, we really need to make our way
own groups to customize permission to

70
00:03:34.210 --> 00:03:34.970
manipulate things.

71
00:03:34.970 --> 00:03:38.000

72
00:03:38.000 --> 00:03:44.337

73

74
00:03:46.460 --> 00:03:50.120
But the change owner command,
where we can change the user or

75

76
00:03:53.240 --> 00:03:56.450
But, if we haven't created
the supporting users and

77

groups yet, it's not very effective and
not a whole lot of point in doing it.

78
00:04:00.020 --> 00:04:01.939
So, that's what we're gonna

79

80

85
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:28.660

86
00:04:28.660 --> 00:04:31.670
All right, now how do I know

87
00:04:31.670 --> 00:04:35.520
Well there are more than just one user

88
00:04:35.520 --> 00:04:38.530
A lot of times there is other ones
that are created by the system and

89
00:04:38.530 --> 00:04:39.330
we can see them.

90
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:42.232
We actually get to see
a little UNIX history here,

00:04:46.740 --> 00:04:50.480

00:04:55.750 --> 00:05:01.870
And that file still exists,

00:05:01.870 --> 00:05:06.540
The file exist and

96
00:05:06.540 --> 00:05:07.500
Okay?

97

Now, when we look at the user

00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:13.040
So, I see route right there.

99
00:05:13.040 --> 00:05:15.560
Right.
And then after I see all of these

00:05:15.560 --> 00:05:17.290
other accounts that I didn't create.

101
00:05:17.290 --> 00:05:18.630
Right.
I didn't make these.

102
00:05:18.630 --> 00:05:20.580
Well, this are part of default install.

103
00:05:20.580 --> 00:05:24.100
I just did a quick and

00:05:24.100 --> 00:05:27.300

00:05:35.300 --> 00:05:38.990
And you'll see there are accounts
tied to various things, so lp,

108
00:05:38.990 --> 00:05:44.660
we're gonna talk about later, that's for

109
00:05:44.660 --> 00:05:47.560
Each of these have different purposes

00:05:47.560 --> 00:05:49.380

111
00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:50.650
Some of them are tied to services

00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:52.650

00:06:04.660 --> 00:06:07.740
Dbus, haldaemon, ntp a lot of those,

118
00:06:07.740 --> 00:06:10.780
a lot of them we're actually going
to work with later on in the show.

119
00:06:12.340 --> 00:06:16.080
The way this file is structured
it's pretty straight forward.

120
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:19.830
What you have is the, actually let
me get back up to the top of it.

121
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:24.060
There we go.

122
00:06:24.060 --> 00:06:28.950
I'm just gonna, kinda, clean it up so I
don't have to, here let me do this, there.

123
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:32.776
I'm just gonna pull it up and see,
I'm just feeding it through grep, so

124
00:06:32.776 --> 00:06:36.190
that, I can get just the root account,
that's all I wanna see.

125
00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:38.890
And so I can see right here,
I've got the root user and

126
00:06:38.890 --> 00:06:41.990
the way the fields work out are like this,
you've got the username, so

127
00:06:41.990 --> 00:06:46.180
that's the name of the user and
it used to be followed by the password.

128
00:06:46.180 --> 00:06:49.780
The password was actually written
right here, this was their password.

129
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:53.300
And then over time, they started to
encrypt it, and things changed, and

130
00:06:53.300 --> 00:06:54.900
so now there's just an X.

131
00:06:54.900 --> 00:06:57.160
And the X is kind of like a placeholder,

132
00:06:57.160 --> 00:07:01.940
saying the password used to be here,
now it's somewhere else.

133
00:07:01.940 --> 00:07:05.360
And then it was followed by the user ID,

134
00:07:05.360 --> 00:07:09.000
Every user that gets created has

135
00:07:09.000 --> 00:07:11.790

136
00:07:13.060 --> 00:07:16.430
It doesn't have to be,

137
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:20.250

it usually is zero.

138
00:07:20.250 --> 00:07:23.590
User accounts that we create
normally start at 500.

139
00:07:23.590 --> 00:07:28.070
And so you'll see 500, 501, 502,
it skips a big chunk at the beginning.

140

01:48:36.550 --> 01:48:38.141
Whoop, I should have filtered that.

1894
01:48:38.141 --> 01:48:39.520
Well, no, I can see it right there.

1895
01:48:39.520 --> 01:48:43.630
So I ran service -- status-all.

1896
01:48:43.630 --> 01:48:47.480
It lists all the services that are running
in the background and their status and so

1897
01:48:47.480 --> 01:48:52.520
I can see on my system,
I have NTPD I could be an NTP server but

1898
01:48:52.520 --> 01:48:54.110
it stopped, I just haven't configured it.

1899
01:48:54.110 --> 01:48:57.820
So, you can turn any server
into an NTP server if you want.

1900
01:49:00.010 --> 01:49:04.200
All right, but for right now, for
this exam, we're just worried about being

1901
01:49:04.200 --> 01:49:07.380
a client, worried about getting a time and
synchronizing it.

1902
01:49:07.380 --> 01:49:13.058
So if I wanna do that, I can edit
the /etc/ntp.com file and I can add in

1903
01:49:13.058 --> 01:49:18.849
my own servers, or if I'm happy with
those, I can just stick with them.

1904
01:49:18.849 --> 01:49:21.239
I can kind of go about
that however I want.

1905
01:49:21.239 --> 01:49:28.761
I'm gonna go in here and
I'm gonna add server 0.us.pool.ntp.org,

1906
01:49:28.761 --> 01:49:35.931
all right, that way I get the NTP
server that is for the United States.

1907
01:49:35.931 --> 01:49:38.523
We're gonna be one,
I don't know which one, but

1908
01:49:38.523 --> 01:49:40.827
it's gonna be one pulled from around here.

1909
01:49:40.827 --> 01:49:46.401
All right, and I don't remember what
the iburst tag on that one does.

1910
01:49:46.401 --> 01:49:49.845
It probably has to deal with how
we send those communications out.

1911
01:49:49.845 --> 01:49:53.610
Cuz time synchronization can be
a very bursty type thing, we send

1912
01:49:53.610 --> 01:49:58.350
a burst of traffic and we expect as low
a latency response as possible back.

1913
01:49:58.350 --> 01:50:00.440
And we communicate,
it's actually more than one thing.

1914
01:50:00.440 --> 01:50:05.060
It sends out a test first to measure
the time difference between the packet

1915
01:50:05.060 --> 01:50:08.500
leaving you, getting to the other side,
and coming back, so

1916
01:50:08.500 --> 01:50:11.180
that it can adjust the time
it gets based on the delay.

1917
01:50:11.180 --> 01:50:12.750
So we're as precise as possible.

1918
01:50:12.750 --> 01:50:14.260
So it may have something to do with that.

1919
01:50:14.260 --> 01:50:18.468
I'll just leave it off,
cuz I don't remember what it does, whoops.

1920
01:50:18.468 --> 01:50:21.350
And I'm gonna leave in some extra
text that will screw things up.

1921
01:50:21.350 --> 01:50:22.860
There we go, all right.

1922
01:50:22.860 --> 01:50:25.328
So now when NTP synchronizes next,

1923
01:50:25.328 --> 01:50:29.283
it'll reach out to these servers and
get the right time.

1924
01:50:29.283 --> 01:50:32.190
And I'm in my right time zone so
everything should be good.

1925
01:50:32.190 --> 01:50:36.110
You can schedule this to run on your
own using a Cron job if you want or

1926
01:50:36.110 --> 01:50:39.200
you can manually kick it
off to have it synchronize.

1927
01:50:39.200 --> 01:50:41.970
So if I wanna force it, I can say ntpdate.

1928
01:50:44.600 --> 01:50:53.060
And then let's do 0.us.pool.ntp.org, okay?

1929
01:50:53.060 --> 01:50:56.850
So NTP date, we have the date
command where we can set the time.

1930
01:50:56.850 --> 01:51:00.130
NTP date says use NTP to set the date.

1931
01:51:00.130 --> 01:51:05.000
And so I can run that, it'll reach out to
that server and get the time and set it.

1932
01:51:05.000 --> 01:51:07.727
And it's setting it very, very precise.

1933
01:51:07.727 --> 01:51:10.664
See that offset -37, whatever?

1934
01:51:10.664 --> 01:51:14.318
That's it measuring the amount of time it
took my packet to get there and back, so

1935
01:51:14.318 --> 01:51:16.486
apparently 37 milliseconds and something.

1936
01:51:16.486 --> 01:51:21.920
So it offset that and corrected so
that my time would be entered in properly.

1937
01:51:21.920 --> 01:51:25.488
Or actually I think it's telling me
there that I'm 37 seconds off, and so

1938
01:51:25.488 --> 01:51:26.392
it's fixed that.

1939
01:51:26.392 --> 01:51:27.893
But I can see that it's set.

1940
01:51:27.893 --> 01:51:31.401
And when I look at my time now,
it's very precise.

1941
01:51:31.401 --> 01:51:36.613
11:43 and 2 seconds, cuz that's
what it got from the other side.

1942
01:51:36.613 --> 01:51:40.015
All right, so
NTP is a great way to handle that.

1943
01:51:40.015 --> 01:51:45.658
If we wanna create a Cron job to do
the NTP updates at a particular interval,

1944
01:51:45.658 --> 01:51:47.637
that's pretty easy too.

1945
01:51:47.637 --> 01:51:54.414
So we can just edit our crontab like we
saw at the beginning of this episode, and

1946
01:51:54.414 --> 01:52:00.388
I'm just gonna add an entry in here and
maybe I wanna update my clock.

1947
01:52:00.388 --> 01:52:04.182
It depends on how sensitive your operation
is, let's say once a day, right?

1948
01:52:04.182 --> 01:52:06.486
So, everyday at midnight,

1949
01:52:06.486 --> 01:52:11.192
everyday at midnight I wanna go ahead and
update my clock.

1950
01:52:11.192 --> 01:52:13.917
So, I'm gonna set the minute and
the hour to 0.

1951
01:52:13.917 --> 01:52:16.563
So, at the very beginning of the day,

1952
01:52:16.563 --> 01:52:20.384
0 hundred hours everyday of the month,
every month.

1953
01:52:20.384 --> 01:52:25.782
Every day of the week as root I
want to perform an action and

1954
01:52:25.782 --> 01:52:30.729
my action is gonna be slash
USR slash bin slash NTPD so

1955
01:52:30.729 --> 01:52:33.557
I'm gonna fire up the demon.

1956
01:52:33.557 --> 01:52:39.997
I'm gonna tell it to run one time,
dash q and for

1957
01:52:39.997 --> 01:52:45.825
the user I'm going to use the ntp process.

1958
01:52:45.825 --> 01:52:50.470
Ntpd-q says to run once,
synchronize the time and exit.

1959
01:52:50.470 --> 01:52:54.760
It's effectively the same as ntp date,
the command I showed you a moment ago.

1960
01:52:54.760 --> 01:52:55.420
All right?

1961
01:52:55.420 --> 01:52:57.440
So why have two commands?

1962
01:52:57.440 --> 01:52:59.895
Well ntpdate is the old command.

1963
01:52:59.895 --> 01:53:02.990
Ntpd-q is the new one.

1964
01:53:02.990 --> 01:53:07.290
So one of these days
ntpdate is gonna go away,

1965
01:53:07.290 --> 01:53:11.310
we're not gonna have that command anymore,
but for now we have both.

1966
01:53:11.310 --> 01:53:15.930
And so they are effectively the same, I
could use ntpdate thing is, I'll probably

1967
01:53:15.930 --> 01:53:20.570
forget about this cron job, and five
years from now when ntpdate goes away,

1968
01:53:20.570 --> 01:53:21.860
I won't remember to come in here and
change it.

1969
01:53:21.860 --> 01:53:22.670
So I'm just going ahead and

1970
01:53:22.670 --> 01:53:26.940
using the new command here to
make sure I'm on the safe side.

1971
01:53:26.940 --> 01:53:31.360
So ntpd -q Is the same thing as ntpdate,
they do the same thing.

1972
01:53:31.360 --> 01:53:34.060
And then -u,
I'm just saying run this as the ntp user.

1973
01:53:34.060 --> 01:53:36.690
It's a service, ntpd is a daemon.

1974
01:53:36.690 --> 01:53:40.076
And so I need to start it as
a particular user, I'm firing up an ntp.

1975
01:53:40.076 --> 01:53:44.530
So this will make it work every single day
at midnight, I'll synchronize my clock.

1976
01:53:44.530 --> 01:53:47.090
If I'm off by five seconds, it'll fix it.

1977
01:53:47.090 --> 01:53:50.672
If I'm off by one second, it'll fix it,
If I'm off by ten minutes, it'll fix it,

1978
01:53:50.672 --> 01:53:51.686
everyday at midnight.

1979
01:53:54.936 --> 01:53:57.370
All right.
I'll go ahead and save that.

1980
01:53:57.370 --> 01:53:57.889
Now I'm in business.

1981
01:54:00.380 --> 01:54:04.240
All right, so when it comes to
our timezone, our localization,

1982
01:54:04.240 --> 01:54:07.750
our clocks, these are things that most of
us don't think about because if you set

1983
01:54:07.750 --> 01:54:11.420
them properly during the install, that's
it you'll never worry about it again.

1984
01:54:11.420 --> 01:54:15.580
But if you need to change them, now
you've seen a couple ways to go about it.

1985
01:54:15.580 --> 01:54:19.450
And, I'll tell you NTP servers
are pretty common place these days.

1986
01:54:19.450 --> 01:54:23.230
Normally what you'll do is you'll
pick one system that your network and

1987
01:54:23.230 --> 01:54:24.890
make it an NTP server.

1988
01:54:24.890 --> 01:54:28.270
And it can synchronize out
against pooled or whatever.

1989
01:54:28.270 --> 01:54:31.170
But it becomes the one judge of and

1990
01:54:31.170 --> 01:54:34.090
then you set all of your other
systems to synchronize time off of it.

1991
01:54:34.090 --> 01:54:36.640
Your routers, your switches,
your firewalls, your servers,

1992
01:54:36.640 --> 01:54:39.410
your workstations,
your voice over IP phones.

1993
01:54:39.410 --> 01:54:42.510
That way the clock is the same
throughout your entire company.

1994
01:54:42.510 --> 01:54:47.620
It makes it really great if you have some
kind of incident, you can follow logs.

1995
01:54:47.620 --> 01:54:51.710
Across your servers and know that 1
pm on one server is the same as 1 pm

1996
01:54:51.710 --> 01:54:53.580
on the other server and
that's really important.

1997
01:54:54.670 --> 01:54:59.390
So all right, well that about
all I've got for localization.

1998
01:54:59.390 --> 01:55:03.510
Yeah, I can't think of anything
else to throw in there.

1999
01:55:03.510 --> 01:55:05.920
So that pretty much wraps that one up,

2000
01:55:05.920 --> 01:55:09.370
I do want to remind everybody that if you
ever have any questions on this stuff.

2001
01:55:09.370 --> 01:55:14.570
Live during the show, go to itpro.tv/live,
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

2002
01:55:14.570 --> 01:55:17.740
You can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

2003
01:55:17.740 --> 01:55:21.266
If you have questions after the show,
use the Q&A forums.

2004
01:55:21.266 --> 01:55:23.380
Hit that Q&A link at the top
of every page in our site,

2005
01:55:23.380 --> 01:55:24.880
it'll take you into the forums.

2006
01:55:24.880 --> 01:55:27.570
You can post your questions there and,
again, we monitor and answer.

2007
01:55:27.570 --> 01:55:30.520
So we want to make sure you guys
get the information you need.

2008
01:55:30.520 --> 01:55:32.565
That resource is there for
you, make use of it.

2009
01:55:32.565 --> 01:55:33.590
>> Mm-hm.

2010
01:55:33.590 --> 01:55:35.155
>> All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

2011
01:55:35.155 --> 01:55:37.407
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

2012
01:55:37.407 --> 01:55:38.197
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

2013
01:55:38.197 --> 01:55:40.078
>> And we will see you next time.

2014

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Don dive into Linux System Services and show configuring system logging and using the basic Mail Transfer Agent within the Linux distro through the CLI. They also configure the use of printers and manage printing through the CLI.
episodes.title: Essential System Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:35.611
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:35.611 --> 00:00:37.731
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:37.731 --> 00:00:40.391
I'm your host Don Pezet,
today with Mr. Nate Copeland.

5
00:00:40.391 --> 00:00:40.971
How's it going, Nate?

6
00:00:40.971 --> 00:00:41.971
>> Yeah, pretty good, Don.

7
00:00:41.971 --> 00:00:43.750
Pretty good.
Glad to be back for

8
00:00:43.750 --> 00:00:48.550
another fantastic bit of Linux+
although no GUI today, so

9
00:00:48.550 --> 00:00:52.782
we'll be moving back into
the keyboard commander.

10
00:00:52.782 --> 00:00:53.702
>> The realm of the unknown.

11
00:00:53.702 --> 00:00:54.202
>> Yeah.

12
00:00:54.202 --> 00:00:56.671
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, Nate's exactly right.

13
00:00:56.671 --> 00:00:59.931
We had our day in the sun with
graphical user interface.

14
00:00:59.931 --> 00:01:03.461
We got a chance to see that interacted
a bit, but we're back to the command line.

15
00:01:03.461 --> 00:01:08.395
So today, we're gonna take
a look at what's objective 108

16
00:01:08.395 --> 00:01:10.731
Essential System Services.

17
00:01:10.731 --> 00:01:14.035
Now the definition of essential
is somewhat debatable, but

18
00:01:14.035 --> 00:01:17.987
most Linux distributions have kind of
agreed on a couple of services that

19
00:01:17.987 --> 00:01:21.452
are important enough to include
with your install by default.

20
00:01:21.452 --> 00:01:25.282
Even when you choose a minimal install,
you'll have a lot of these services.

21
00:01:25.282 --> 00:01:27.271
So, we're gonna take
a look at some of them.

22
00:01:27.271 --> 00:01:28.071
How they work?

23
00:01:28.071 --> 00:01:28.771
What they do?

24
00:01:28.771 --> 00:01:30.231
How they can interact with them?

25
00:01:30.231 --> 00:01:32.651
And kind of move through that.

26
00:01:32.651 --> 00:01:35.171
We're starting to kind of
wind down on our objectives.

27
00:01:35.171 --> 00:01:39.111
We only have security and networking
after this, so the end is neigh.

28
00:01:39.111 --> 00:01:44.222
The end is in site for, not so
much for neigh, but it's come along.

29
00:01:44.222 --> 00:01:46.582
We're almost to the end.

30
00:01:46.582 --> 00:01:49.971
Well, what are some essential services?

31
00:01:49.971 --> 00:01:52.447
Well, if you're spinning
up a Linux server,

32
00:01:52.447 --> 00:01:56.572
the essential services are simply the ones
you need to achieve your goal, but

33
00:01:56.572 --> 00:01:59.761
your goal may be very different
than the rest of the planet.

34
00:01:59.761 --> 00:02:04.401
If you're spinning up a web server, then
you really need a web service on there.

35
00:02:04.401 --> 00:02:06.881
Maybe Apache or something of that nature.

36
00:02:06.881 --> 00:02:10.721
And so to you,
Apache is an essential service.

37
00:02:10.721 --> 00:02:15.672
But if I'm spinning up an email server,
what do I care about a web server?

38
00:02:15.672 --> 00:02:17.531
So, it's not essential service to me.

39
00:02:17.531 --> 00:02:20.865
So just keep that in mind that
this is a little subjective,

40
00:02:20.865 --> 00:02:23.121
whatever it is that view as essential.

41
00:02:23.121 --> 00:02:27.403
But on the exam, we have a specific
list that we need to adhere to and

42
00:02:27.403 --> 00:02:30.631
the first one is one that
is really hard to debate.

43
00:02:30.631 --> 00:02:33.420
It's the syslog daemon.

44
00:02:33.420 --> 00:02:36.690
Syslog is the system log for

45
00:02:36.690 --> 00:02:41.150
Unix and Linux and it is a service
that runs in the background.

46
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:46.362
And anytime there are messages,
status updates, critical alerts, errors,

47
00:02:46.362 --> 00:02:51.419
crashes, information, any kind of
general activity that generates data,

48
00:02:51.419 --> 00:02:55.030
it's gonna be logging that
into a log file somewhere.

49
00:02:55.030 --> 00:02:58.410
And I know we've dabbled in to a little
bit in some of the previous episode.

50
00:02:58.410 --> 00:03:01.561
We saw the log file,
we saw log rotate in the cron episode.

51
00:03:01.561 --> 00:03:05.930
So we've seen it, but
we haven't really looked at it directly.

52
00:03:05.930 --> 00:03:08.530
Now, syslog is an integral part of Linux.

53
00:03:08.530 --> 00:03:12.969
I cannot think of a single distribution
that does not have it installed and

54
00:03:12.969 --> 00:03:14.340
turned on by default.

55
00:03:14.340 --> 00:03:18.960
So, it's almost a given that it's going
to be there and running on your system.

56
00:03:18.960 --> 00:03:21.191
If your not sure,
there's an easy way to check.

57
00:03:21.191 --> 00:03:23.020
Let me bring my system up.

58
00:03:23.020 --> 00:03:26.124
Now this system, if you watched
the last episode, I went ahead and

59
00:03:26.124 --> 00:03:27.020
wiped my machine.

60
00:03:27.020 --> 00:03:31.780
So, this is a stock install of CentOS 6.5.

61
00:03:31.780 --> 00:03:34.925
Now I've created a few user accounts and
groups in it from that previous episode,

62
00:03:34.925 --> 00:03:37.905
but the only other thing I've done is
configure the network of that product.

63
00:03:37.905 --> 00:03:39.025
The rest of it is all stock.

64
00:03:39.025 --> 00:03:43.015
I've not actually installed
any software on it at all.

65
00:03:43.015 --> 00:03:47.913
And if I do a service --status-all and
I'll just grep that for

66
00:03:47.913 --> 00:03:53.085
the word log since there's several
different logs that are there,

67
00:03:53.085 --> 00:03:56.910
I can run that and
I'll see rsyslogd right there.

68
00:03:56.910 --> 00:04:00.008
That is the syslog game and
it's running in the background,

69
00:04:00.008 --> 00:04:02.510
it's catching those log files and
it's there.

70
00:04:02.510 --> 00:04:06.310
You can see where I checked just before
the shows just to make sure it was there.

71
00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:08.001
Of course, it is.

72
00:04:08.001 --> 00:04:10.341
>> So with the syslog being.

73
00:04:10.341 --> 00:04:13.962
So all the information stuff and
things that happened,

74
00:04:13.962 --> 00:04:18.750
what about application stuff or
anything else that's running on there?

75
00:04:18.750 --> 00:04:20.830
Does it also get logged to the syslog?

76
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:23.010
>> It can, most applications do.

77
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:26.870
So when you run another server, like
say I bring up an email server on here.

78
00:04:26.870 --> 00:04:30.370
Your email server is mostly likely
logging to your syslog server too.

79
00:04:30.370 --> 00:04:33.270
Now I say most likely, they don't have to.

80
00:04:33.270 --> 00:04:37.177
By default, your operating system,
your Linux distribution,

81
00:04:37.177 --> 00:04:42.161
it will log the syslog, but all the third
party software you install may or may not.

82
00:04:42.161 --> 00:04:45.477
If they create a system of that like
if they caused a segment fault, well,

83
00:04:45.477 --> 00:04:47.520
the kernel will detect that, it'll log it.

84
00:04:47.520 --> 00:04:50.650
And so, that'll make it in regardless of
what the application was configured for.

85
00:04:50.650 --> 00:04:53.680
Because well, at that point,
the application's crashed.

86
00:04:53.680 --> 00:04:56.310
But if it's something like
the printing system and

87
00:04:56.310 --> 00:04:58.510
you send a print job out to a printer,

88
00:04:58.510 --> 00:05:01.650
it's up to the printing system to decide
whether or not it's going to log that.

89
00:05:02.820 --> 00:05:05.831
And our own scripts, things that we write.

90
00:05:05.831 --> 00:05:09.089
When we write a script
to perform activities,

91
00:05:09.089 --> 00:05:12.270
they can log to syslog
also if we tell them to.

92
00:05:12.270 --> 00:05:15.140
Now we wrote some scripts
in earlier episodes and

93
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:19.130
we didn't do any logging in there,
so our aren't reporting back.

94
00:05:19.130 --> 00:05:22.090
We can make the do that, if we want.

95
00:05:22.090 --> 00:05:24.924
So to get an idea of some of
the things that do get logged, well,

96
00:05:24.924 --> 00:05:26.800
let's take a look at the log file itself.

97
00:05:26.800 --> 00:05:32.351
The log file is stored in /var/log.

98
00:05:32.351 --> 00:05:34.971
And if you look in there,

00:03:50.154 --> 00:03:55.148
So, the first thing you need to be
aware of is, how an IP address and

77
00:03:55.148 --> 00:03:57.213
subnet mask works, okay?

78
00:03:57.213 --> 00:04:00.500
Normally when we get an IP address,
it's two pieces.

79
00:04:00.500 --> 00:04:06.084
There's the IP address,
something like 192.168.0.1.

80
00:04:06.084 --> 00:04:08.254
And there's the subnet mask,

81
00:04:08.254 --> 00:04:13.525
which is normally something
like 255.255.255.0, right?

82
00:04:13.525 --> 00:04:15.462
Something like that, okay?

83
00:04:15.462 --> 00:04:20.131
Those are IP addresses and
what they're signifying is,

84
00:04:20.131 --> 00:04:24.980
part of this address is
referring to my network.

85
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:29.670
And part of this address is referring
to my machine, or this particular node,

86
00:04:29.670 --> 00:04:31.570
it's got that entry.

87
00:04:31.570 --> 00:04:33.708
And the subnet mask is telling
me where that division is.

88
00:04:33.708 --> 00:04:38.869
By seeing 255.255.255 right here,
that's telling me the first 3 values,

89
00:04:38.869 --> 00:04:42.700
they're called octets cuz
they're made up of 8 bits each.

90
00:04:42.700 --> 00:04:45.586
The first 3 octets represent the network,
and

91
00:04:45.586 --> 00:04:49.570
the last octet is a 1 here,
the 0 tells me that that's the host.

92
00:04:49.570 --> 00:04:51.534
So my host is .1.

93
00:04:51.534 --> 00:04:55.934
There might be a .2, a .3, a .4, those
are the other computers on my network.

94
00:04:55.934 --> 00:04:59.987
And as long as their addresses
start with 192.168.0,

95
00:04:59.987 --> 00:05:04.440
then I know that they are on the same
network as me and I can talk to them.

96
00:05:04.440 --> 00:05:08.080
Right, now there are three
major classes of addresses.

97
00:05:08.080 --> 00:05:12.297
There's Class A, Class B and Class C and

98
00:05:12.297 --> 00:05:16.850
each of them uses a different subnet mask.

99
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:21.730
So a Class A uses 255.0.0.0,
a Class B uses 255.255.0.0,

100
00:05:21.730 --> 00:05:27.210
and a Class C uses that guy right there.

101
00:05:27.210 --> 00:05:30.120
And so, you'll see,
it's a difference in how many

102
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:34.830
octets are attached to the network and
how many octets are attached to the host.

103
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:39.080
The more octets you have attached to
your host, the more hosts you can have.

104
00:05:39.080 --> 00:05:40.780
And Ron,
you've got these memorized, right?

105
00:05:40.780 --> 00:05:43.149
A class A is what, like 16.7 million?

106
00:05:43.149 --> 00:05:47.134
>> 16,777,214.

107
00:05:47.134 --> 00:05:51.429
>> [LAUGH] 16,770,214?

108
00:05:51.429 --> 00:05:53.287
>> 77,000.

109
00:05:53.287 --> 00:05:55.539
>> 777,000, like that?

110
00:05:55.539 --> 00:05:56.407
How do you memorize this stuff?

111
00:05:56.407 --> 00:05:59.366
[LAUGH] Anyhow,
>> 2 to the 24th power.

112
00:05:59.366 --> 00:06:00.340
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

113
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:01.790
I know you did that math in your head.

114
00:06:01.790 --> 00:06:05.390
Anyhow so,
you can have that many hosts on a Class A.

115
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:11.054
At Class B it is 65,534 or 5?

116
00:06:11.054 --> 00:06:12.540
>> 4, yep.

117
00:06:12.540 --> 00:06:14.166
>> See, I remember some things.

118
00:06:14.166 --> 00:06:19.413
And then a Class C is a meager 254 hosts.

119
00:06:19.413 --> 00:06:23.821
Okay, so the classes,
the more octets we attach to the network,

120
00:06:23.821 --> 00:06:27.020
the fewer hosts we can
have on our network.

121
00:06:27.020 --> 00:06:31.340
And for a home network or a small
business, 254 hosts is more than enough.

122
00:06:31.340 --> 00:06:35.440
And so we see Class C
networks almost all the time.

123
00:06:35.440 --> 00:06:39.020
But in a business where you might
have well over 250 machines,

124
00:06:39.020 --> 00:06:43.080
you might use Class Bs or
even Class As to give you enough room.

125
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:47.440
All right, so that's one concept that
we need to be aware of for the exam.

126
00:06:47.440 --> 00:06:50.840
Just how IP addresses work and
what those subnet masks mean.

127

All right, again,

128

00:06:59.910 --> 00:07:03.393
All right,
the other thing we need to be aware of is,

131
00:07:03.393 --> 00:07:07.607
some addresses are private, and
some are public, all right.

132
00:07:07.607 --> 00:07:10.159
Private IPs,
you can use to your heart's content,

133
00:07:10.159 --> 00:07:14.170
you don't have to tell anybody you can
use them, you're on your own, all right?

134
00:07:14.170 --> 00:07:19.240
Public IPs are ones that are unique
across the entire Internet.

135
00:07:19.240 --> 00:07:22.570
And the way that uniqueness is
enforced is that if you wanna use one,

136
00:07:22.570 --> 00:07:26.590
you have to register it with the INA or
one of those other providers.

137
00:07:26.590 --> 00:07:28.510
So you usually have to buy or

138
00:07:28.510 --> 00:07:33.440
rent these IP addresses from
a service provider to get them.

139
00:07:33.440 --> 00:07:37.170
Private IPs, and
these are defined in RFC 1918 if you're

140
00:07:37.170 --> 00:07:39.814
one of those people that likes
to go read and standards.

141
00:07:40.910 --> 00:07:45.726
Private IPs, I'm not one of them,
private IPs for the Class A networks,

142

do it over an encrypted connection.

1265
01:10:17.155 --> 01:10:18.734

1266
01:10:18.734 --> 01:10:20.763
Telnet would give us a remote shell,

1267
01:10:20.763 --> 01:10:24.506

in plaintext across the network.

1268
01:10:24.506 --> 01:10:25.416
Your username,

1269
01:10:25.416 --> 01:10:30.102
your password, your commands, the output
on your screen, all that was plaintext.

1270
01:10:30.102 --> 01:10:33.260
Anybody can fire up a network sniffer,
capture the data.

1271
01:10:33.260 --> 01:10:35.594
And now, you're just screwed.

1272
01:10:35.594 --> 01:10:37.718
So, ssh fixes that.

1273
01:10:37.718 --> 01:10:40.720
Sshbuilds a shell just like telnet does,
but

1274
01:10:40.720 --> 01:10:44.917
it encrypts every single
communication between the systems.

1275
01:10:44.917 --> 01:10:51.361

ships with ssh installed and turned on.

02:05:27.090 --> 02:05:32.030

02:05:32.030 --> 02:05:34.930

02:05:34.930 --> 02:05:39.230

02:05:39.230 --> 02:05:43.910

02:05:43.910 --> 02:05:46.080

02:05:46.080 --> 02:05:49.350

02:05:49.350 --> 02:05:53.240

02:05:53.240 --> 02:05:55.760

02:06:03.980 --> 02:06:04.650

02:06:04.650 --> 02:06:06.172
All its stuff is right

02:06:06.172 --> 02:06:13.470
So SELinux is configured with a policy

2281
02:06:13.470 --> 02:06:17.860

02:06:17.860 --> 02:06:20.370

02:06:20.370 --> 02:06:24.590

02:06:24.590 --> 02:06:29.650

02:06:29.650 --> 02:06:33.760

02:06:33.760 --> 02:06:38.360

02:08:52.430 --> 02:08:56.810
